Should I study or should I go (to sleep)? The
influence of test schedule on the sleep
behavior of undergraduate s and its
association with performance
Ignacio Estevan
ID
1
*, Romina Sardi
1
, Ana Clara Tejera
1
, Ana Silva
2
, Bettina Tassino
3
1 Programa de Neuropsic ologı ´ a y Neurobi ologı ´ a, Facultad de Psicologı ´ a, Universidad de la Repu ´ blica,
Montevideo , Uruguay, 2 Laboratori o de Neurocien cias, Facultad de Ciencias , Universidad de la Repu ´ blica,
Montevideo , Uruguay, 3 Seccio ´ n Etologı ´ a, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la Repu ´ blica, Montev ideo,
Uruguay
* iestevan@ psico.edu.u y
Abstract
Sleep is crucial for college students’ well-being. Although recommende d sleep duration is
between 7–9 hours per day, many students do not sleep that much. Scholar demands are
among the causes of observed sleep deprivation in youth. We explored the influence of hav-
ing a school test on previous night sleep in first-year students and the association of sleep
duration and test performance. We ran two surveys in freshman students of the Universidad
de la Repu ´ blica, Montevideo, Uruguay: 1) 97 students of the School of Sciences who took
the test at the same time; and 2) 252 School of Psychology students who took the test in
four successive shifts. More than 1/2 of the participants (survey #1) and almost 1/3 (survey
#2) reported short regular sleep duration (< 7h). In both samples, the sleep duration of the
night before the test was reduced with respect to regular nights (survey #1: 2.1 ± 0.2 h, p <
0.001; survey #2: between 1.7 ± 0.4 h and 3.6 ± 0.3 h, all p < 0.001), with more than 10% of
the students who did not sleep at all. In survey 2, sleep duration increased in later shifts (F
(3,248) = 4.6, p = 0.004). Using logit regressions, we confirmed that sleep duration was posi-
tively related to test scores in both samples (survey #1: exp B = 1.15, p < 0.001; pseudo-R
2
= 0.38; survey #2: exp B = 1.03, p < 0.001; pseudo-R
2
= 0.25). Delaying test start time may
prevent the reduction in sleep duration, which may also improve school performance. In
addition, educational policies should include information for students about the impact of
sleep on learning and of the consequences of reduced sleep duration.
Introduction
There is a consensus that adults should sleep between 7–9 hours per day [1, 2]. Chronic short
sleep duration is associated with an increase in several risk factors [3], and with an increase in
the relative risk for multiple-cause mortality [4]. However, according to the Centers for Dis-
ease Control and Prevention [5], more than 30% of American young adults report short sleep

duration (i.e. < 7h), and a recent meta-analysis showed a mean sleep duration among medical
undergraduate students of 6.3 h per night [6].
It is well documented that biological and psycho-social changes during adolescence along
with social pressures strongly influence high-school students’ short sleep duration [7–9]. In
particular, the compromise between the natural trend of adolescents towards Eveningness and
their early school schedule has been pointed out as a key factor affecting sleep duration and
quality [10, 11]. Young college undergraduate students still exhibit a delayed chronotype [12],
and display a shorter sleep duration when attending morning classes with respect to evening
classes [13].
Sleep is related to students’ well-being and mental health [14–17]. Moreover, students’ sleep
duration, sleep pattern, and daytime sleepiness have been proved to affect their academic per-
formance [18–21]. Comparing sleep problems to other factors influencing academic perfor-
mance, Hartman & Prichard [22] found that sleep problems have similar influence in school
retention and grades than other factors that receive more attention such as binge drinking or
drug consumption.
Despite the relevance of sufficient sleep duration, there is some evidence that students
reduce their sleep during exam periods and the night before a test [23]. An actigraphy study
with final-year high school students showed a reduction in sleep duration, quality, and effi-
ciency [24]. It has been interpreted that the increase in psychological distress and anxiety typi-
cal of exams periods affect both sleep duration and quality [23–27]. In addition to anxiety,
using a survey with undergraduate students, Hartwig & Dunlosky [28] showed that more than
half the participants often do all their study in one session previous to the test, and most of
them also “cram” lots of information in this previous night sacrificing sleep hours with no ben-
efits in their performance. In a study with American college students, almost 60% of them
reported engaging at least once in all-night study sessions, which hampered their test perfor-
mance [29]. Orzerch et al. [30] also found better grades among students not reporting all-
night study sessions. However, other studies did not find an association between long night
study sessions and test scores [31, 32].
Although the positive association of sleep duration and academic performance seems to be
well established, the influence of tests on sleep is not yet fully understood, and studies about
the consequences of an acute sleep reduction previous to a test are scarce. In this study, we
took advantage of the highly populated freshman University courses of the Universidad de la
Repu ´ blica, Uruguay, that require students to take tests in different shifts. We aimed to clarify
how students modify their sleep habits the night before they take a test and to evaluate the
association between sleep duration and academic performance.
Materials and methods
We ran two surveys in freshman students of the Universidad de la Repu ´ blica, Montevideo,
Uruguay. We used a short computer-based questionnaire to ask about students’ sleep pattern
(bedtime, sleep latency, sleep end) on regular nights and the night before a mid-term test that
was applied immediately after students finished the test. Questionnaire also included some
items about socio-demographic information.
Statistical analyses were performed in R [33] using RStudio as an integrated development
environment [34]. Throughout the text sample statistics are reported as Mean ± Standard
Deviation, while estimated differences are reported as Mean ± Standard Error. All procedures
were approved by the Ethics Committee of the School of Psychology, Universidad de la Repu ´ -
blica, and complied with the principles outlined by the Declaration of Helsinki [35]. All partic-
ipants gave their informed consent to participate using a digital form.

Survey #1
Undergraduate students of the first year semi-annual course of General Biology of the School
of Sciences, Universidad de la Repu ´ blica, were invited to participate in this study after finishing
the mid-term test in May 2019. Ninety seven students agreed to participate (Table 1), repre-
senting the 33.5% of the students who took the test. The number of correct answers for each
participant in the 20 multiple-choice questions test was provided by the course teachers. Test
score represent 1/3 of the final grade.
Survey #2
Undergraduate students of the Psychology School, Universidad de la Repu ´ blica, who took the
mid-term test of Neurobiology course in June 2019 were invited to participate in this study.
Neurobiology is a first year semiannual course, and almost 2200 students (74.2% females)
began their grade studies in Psychology in 2019 [36]. As 1358 students took the test, they were
randomly distributed in four different shifts (see schedule in Table 1). Each one of the four test
versions consisted of 60 similar true/false questions. Two hundred fifty two students agreed to
participate (Table 1), representing the 18.6% of the students who took the test. In survey #2, a
question inquiring about the total time spent studying previous to the test was added (“How
many hours do you spend studying adding up yesterday and today hours previous to the
test?”). The number of correct answers of each participant was provided by the course teachers.
Test score represent 1/2 of the final grade.

the first shift and 69.0% for a student who slept 8 h and attended the fourth shift. Mean number
of hours spent studying before the test was 8.0 ± 5.0 h, with no difference between test shifts (F
(3, 248) = 2.25, p = 0.08). Number of hours spent studying did not correlate with sleep before
the test (r = -0.10, p = 0.3) nor with test performance (r = 0.03, p = 0.6).
Discussion
In this study, we present data to evaluate the influence of tests on freshman college students’
sleep behavior and the influence of sleep on their academic performance. Although these issues
have been addressed in previous reports [23, 24, 31, 32], this is the first study to explore how
sleep patterns of the night before the test change when the test is taken at different times (sur-
vey #2). Overall (survey #1 and #2), most students delayed their bedtime the night before the
test, reducing their sleep duration, and more than 10% did not even sleep at all the night
before. Even when the test started as late as 13:15, the sleep duration of the night before was
shorter than in regular nights, and 10% of the students stayed awake all night. In addition,
sleep duration was positively correlated with the number of correct answers in the test, and
therefore with school grades. When analyzing these effects across shifts (survey #2), we found
that sleep duration and academic performance improved as test start times were delayed.
High rate of short regular sleep was found in both surveys, with more than 1/2 (survey #1)
and almost 1/3 of students (survey #2) who reported sleep duration <7 h in average per night.
The rate of students with short regular sleep was higher and mean sleep duration was shorter
in students of School of Science (survey #1) than in students of the Psychology School (survey
#2), probably because the former were younger than the latter [37]. Similar values of sleep dep-
rivation were previously reported in Uruguayan university students [38], and this should be a
matter of concern based on the multiple consequences of chronic inadequate sleep [14–17].
Taking the test had a strong influence in the night before sleep behavior of students, a pat-
tern that has been previously described using both actigraphy data and questionnaires in
young students [23, 24].

High rate of short regular sleep was found in both surveys, with more than 1/2 (survey #1)
and almost 1/3 of students (survey #2) who reported sleep duration <7 h in average per night.
The rate of students with short regular sleep was higher and mean sleep duration was shorter
in students of School of Science (survey #1) than in students of the Psychology School (survey
#2), probably because the former were younger than the latter [37]. Similar values of sleep dep-
rivation were previously reported in Uruguayan university students [38], and this should be a
matter of concern based on the multiple consequences of chronic inadequate sleep [14–17].
Taking the test had a strong influence in the night before sleep behavior of students, a pat-
tern that has been previously described using both actigraphy data and questionnaires in
young students [23, 24]. As stated by Hartwig & Dunlosky [28], sleep reduction seems to be a
consequence of giving up hours of sleep to obtain more study hours prior to the test. We con-
firmed this general pattern in the present study as students of both surveys delayed their time
to go to bed the night before the test in about 1 h, regardless of test start times.
Several previous studies reported a positive association between regular sleep duration and
grades [32, 39–42], while others highlight the importance of regular sleep quality, rather than
duration, on academic performance [39, 40, 43, 44]. We observed an association of regular
sleep duration and test performance only in survey #1, as the odds ratio of correct answers
PLOS ONE
Test schedule, sleep and perform ance in undergrad uates
PLOS ONE | https://doi.or g/10.137 1/journal.po ne.02471 04 March 10, 2021 5 / 9

increased with sleep duration. Sleep duration on the night before the test did predict test per-
formance in survey #2, and was a better predictor of performance in survey #1 compared to
regular sleep. In Uruguay, grades use a non-linear scale from 0 to 12. The fair lowest passing
grade is 3 and corresponds to 60% achievement, while 90% achievement corresponds to grade
10. This complexity of the Uruguayan grading system prevented us from using grades in
regressions. However, in both surveys when predicted correct answer rate was converted to
grades 8 h-sleepers obtained a passing grade while all-nighters did not. Scullin [45] found a
similar result using actigraphy data and showing that long-sleep students outperform short-
sleep students in tests scores. The difference between surveys in regression coefficients and
explained deviance may be related with the different type of questions (true/false vs multiple
choice) employed in both courses, as the probability of answering correctly at random is
higher in true-false type questions.
School and test shifts, an obligated solution to the insufficient universities’ infrastructure to
deal with the progressively increasing number of students in many countries [46], can also be
seen as an opportunistic tool to deepen the study of the influence of test start time on sleep and
performance [47–49]. In survey #2, we found that the sleep duration of the night before the
test increased as test start time was delayed. A previous study in Brazilian undergraduate stu-
dents attending school in different shifts found a similar pattern [13]: sleep duration was lon-
ger in students of the afternoon-shift with respect to morning-shift ones. We also found that
students’ performance was significantly higher in later shifts with respect to early ones. The
enhanced performance of late-shift students is more likely due to their longer sleep duration
and not to the time spent studying the day before the test, which was not significantly different
across shifts. In addition to longer sleep durations, chronotype-associated differences in per-
formance may also contribute to the differences observed between shifts [50, 51]. To address
this issue in the future, we plan to add the assessment of Morningness-Eveningn ess in students
of the Psychology School taking tests in different shifts.
Our study has several limitations. Self-report questionnaires may overestimate sleep dura-
tion compared to objective measures [52], and short sleep prevalence may be even higher than
reported among Uruguayan college students. Although data were collected immediately after
the test to prevent memory blurring, future studies should include more objective measures to
confirm our results. A previous study using actigraphy data found a similar pattern of sleep
reduction during exam period [45]. Sleep disturbance and reduced performance may be both
associated with the high levels of anxiety prior to a test [53]. However, we did not observe an
increase in sleep latency before the test, a measure that has been related to anxiety levels [14,
54]. Nevertheless, the analysis of personality-linked variables could help to get a better under-
standing of the interaction between students’ sleep behavior and study practice before a test.
In this study, we show that many college students reported not getting enough sleep. In
addition, we found that taking a test influences students’ sleep behavior, and that the sleep
duration of the night before the test is associated with test performance. Given the relevance of
adequate sleep, it appears as a cost-efficient way to improve student’s academic performance
and well-being [21, 55]. Although delaying school (and tests) start times has been related to
longer sleep duration and better academic performance, it seems not enough. These evidence
should inspire educational policies and promote an open communication of the impact of
sleep on learning and of the consequences of reduced sleep duration.

Article
This study examined perceptions of a music education 
graduate advisor (Carol) and three PhD students (Elle, 
Matt, and Steve)1 in a self-study of individual and collec-
tive experiences from 2010–2011. The key question was: 
How do the PhD students describe experiences specifi-
cally in relation to perceived potential as teachers of grad-
uate students in higher education? Although the primary 
purpose of the self-study was to inform the research site 
and improve teaching practices locally, findings from this 
self-study will help further the recent interest in examin-
ing graduate programs in music education (Rutkowski, 
Webster, & Gossett, 2012, 2013). It is also hoped that the 
approach to self-study described here may encourage 
other researchers in different teaching contexts to study 
their own practices through similar techniques.
In The Formation of Scholars: Rethinking Doctoral 
Education for the Twenty-first Century, Walker, Golde, 
Jones, Bueschel, and Hutchings (2008) outlined the many 
complexities involved in preparing the next generation of 
scholars. They reported on a 5-year project completed by the 
Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching to 
“develop creative solutions and approaches for transforming 
doctoral programs” (front flap). Walker et
 
al. (2008) stated,
Faculty members must be willing to ask for help, which 
requires some humility and vulnerability, but has the payoff 
of becoming a better mentor. . . . Faculty and students alike 
can begin by examining what they do now and assessing 
whether it works. (p. 115)
First and foremost, we urge faculty to see the doctoral 
education experience through the eyes of a student. Ask 
yourself the questions about your doctoral program that you 
would expect a student to ask. And ask the students 
themselves! . . . We encourage you to turn your scholarly 
lenses on the experiences of students in your programs. This 
might mean careful one-on-one conversations, more 
systematic surveys and focus groups, or regular town 
meetings where students are seriously listened to. You might 
be surprised at what you see and hear. (p. 145)
This self-study is a response to this need to listen to grad-
uate students.
Scholarship on Graduate Education 
in Music Education
In one of the earliest articles that examined graduate edu-
cation within music education, the Committee on 
Graduate Study in Music Education (1954) provided a 
rationale for the need for advanced degrees in music

Learning to Teach Graduate Students: 
A Self-Study by Students and a Faculty 
Member
Colleen Conway1, C. Michael Palmer2, Scott Edgar3,  
and Erin Hansen4
Abstract
This study examined our perceptions as a music education professor and three PhD students as we conducted a 
self-study of our individual and collective experiences teaching graduate students. We framed our work around the 
key question: How do PhD students describe experiences specifically in relation to perceived potential as teachers of 
graduate students in higher education? Findings concerning graduate teaching included (a) views of graduate teaching 
changed with increased experience, and (b) confidence increased with more experience teaching graduate classes 
and more time to process the content. The use of self-study as an approach to inquiry is discussed along with these 
findings.

Conway et al. 55
education and defined the various master
’s and doctoral 
degrees at the time. The committee stated that finding a 
balance between music and professional education 
coursework was a key challenge in both master’s and 
doctoral degrees. There was little discussion in this article 
on the topic of research or the creation of scholars and 
teacher educators. However, the article does mention that 
doctoral students should be familiar with the “instru-
ments of research” (p. 168), including proficiency in mul-
tiple foreign languages.
In a Music Educators Journal article, Ball et
 
al. (1980) 
presented the report of the MENC Commission on 
Graduate Music Teacher Education submitted at the con-
clusion of a 4-year focus by the commission. They dis-
cussed graduate teacher education function, curricula, 
faculty, admissions, resources, and the role of research. 
The role of research section suggested that students in the 
master’s program should experience “guided interpreta-
tion” and “practical application” (p. 48), while doctoral 
students must balance research and music requirements. 
The authors heavily criticized the profession for not pro-
ducing qualified researchers at the time. This article  
provides a strong reference list of key historic articles on 
graduate education and research within music education, 
including Britton (1969), Cady (1965), Leonhard and 
Colwell (1976), and Petzold (1964).
Within music teacher education, a Preparing Teacher 
Educators Area for Strategic Planning and Action has 
been formed within the Society for Music Teacher 
Education to examine doctoral programs (Rutkowski, 
Hewitt, Taggart, & Weaver, 2007). Rutkowski et
 
al. 
(2007) presented an extensive overview of current prac-
tices in doctoral education including: (a) identification 
and recruitment of potential doctoral students; (b) suc-
cessful mentoring of doctoral students; (c) working with 
faculty to develop skills in teaching college students, 
including having opportunities teaching college classes; 
(d) sharing the job search process and providing mock-
interview and dossier-compilation experiences; (e) men-
toring students as researchers prior to dissertation work; 
and (f) developing a sense of a community of scholars 
among doctoral students and music education faculty.
Robinson and Taggart (2011) conducted interviews 
with eight recent music education PhD graduates of 
Michigan State University to describe what graduates 
believed had helped to prepare them for their roles as 
new faculty members. They learned that a flat hierarchi-
cal structure (between students and faculty) that involves 
an “ethic of care” (Robinson & Taggart, 2011, p. 17) 
among faculty and peers was perceived as valuable. 
Robinson and Taggart also documented the importance 
of collegiality and collaboration among the doctoral stu-
dents, accessibility to faculty for mentoring, and shared 
that doctoral students valued learning experiences that 
were well balanced between teaching and research/
scholarly activities. Finally, the expectation to conduct, 
present, and publish research emerged as an essential 
and valuable part of the learning community culture.
Method
This inquiry drew from a self-study of teacher education 
research approach (Loughran, 2004, 2007; Russell & 
Loughran, 2007; Samaras, 2011). In a previous self-study 
that examined the preparation of music education PhD 
students for teaching preservice students, Conway, Eros, 
Pellegrino, and West (2010) suggested,
We (graduate students and the professor) have learned about 
ourselves and our students through the process of self-study. 
Although self-study is a fairly new approach within music 
education, we have been guided by the large body of research 
in general education in this area and hope that other music 
education researchers will explore self-study of teacher 
education’s applicability to music. We feel that this study 
has begun to document the growth process experienced by 
PhD students as they study to become teacher educators, but 
the profession needs much more information on this 
important phase in music education. (p. 62)
The study reported here was modeled after Conway et al. 
(2010), but focused on preparation for graduate teaching.

W
ith regard to self-study in music education, 
Matsunobu and Bresler (2014) suggested,
In addition to the types of qualitative research discussed in 
music education research, including case study, narrative, and 
ethnographic methods, other forms of qualitative research, 
such as auto-ethnography (Bartleet & Ellis, 2009; Manovski, 
2012), self-study (Conway et
 
al., 2010), and performance 
ethnography (Denzin, 2003), are relatively uncharted. (p. 33)
Self-study was used in order to learn about ourselves, our 
program, and ultimately, to seek improvement of gradu-
ate teacher education through reflection and self-inquiry.
Doctoral Program Curricula for Graduate 
Teaching Preparation
This study was conducted at a large Midwestern research 
university. The doctoral program at our institution 
includes four core music education courses required of 
both MM and PhD students: Research, History and 
Philosophy of Music Education, Psychology of Music 
Teaching, and Curriculum and Assessment. Elle, Matt, 
and Steve had been colleagues in those courses in 2009–
2010 while Elle was completing the master of music 
degree and Steve and Matt were starting the PhD. In 
2010–2011, Elle, Matt, and Steve participated in three

doctoral-level courses together (Historical and Qualitative 
Research Design, Quantitative and Mixed Methods 
Research Design, and Seminar in Music 
Teacher 
Education), in addition to Doctoral Seminar.
The PhD program at this university had been designed 
intentionally to allow students the opportunity to begin to 
learn how to teach both undergraduate and graduate stu-
dents. At the time of the study, graduate students assisted 
faculty in teaching all of the undergraduate courses as 
well as observing student teachers. PhD students also 
were invited to give guest lectures in the MM program, 
observe MM final oral presentations, thesis proposals, 
and defense presentations, and they were invited (time 
permitting) to provide written feedback to MM thesis 
proposals and final papers.
During the 2010–2011 year, Elle, Matt, and Steve were 
coauthors (with Carol) in a research study examining action 
research and teacher research as a professional develop-
ment activity for inservice teachers. All seven of the teacher 
participants in that study had either recently completed the 
MM degree or were completing the MM degree at our 
school. Data collection for that study provided the PhD stu-
dents an opportunity to work with teachers who were recent 
graduate students as well as the opportunity to do research 
with an experienced faculty mentor.
Doctoral student participants were also in courses with 
MM students (inside and outside of music education) that 
provided opportunities for informal and class interac-
tions. In addition, during the study time period, all three 
doctoral student participants made presentations at state 
and regional conferences where both preservice and 
inservice teachers were the audience.
Participants
Carol. Carol had been teaching at the university since 
2001 and had been the Director of Graduate Studies in 
Music Education since 2004. She was the curriculum 
advisor for Elle, Matt, and Steve and had worked with 
them in coursework 
and individual interactions. Her role 
in the study was one of facilitator as the focus examined 
the student experiences.
Elle.
 Elle entered the PhD program in the fall of 2010 and 
had been in residence completing the MM degree in 
2009–2010. She entered the MM program after 9 years 
teaching elementary through high school orchestra and 
guitar and had worked 
previously with Carol as a student 
in a workshop that Carol had taught, as well as serving as 
a participant in research studies. At the time of the study, 
she was beginning her first year in the PhD program (but 
her second year in residence at the university).
Matt.
 Matt entered the PhD program in the fall of 2009 
after 
8 years teaching elementary through high school 
instrumental and general music. His previous educational 
experience included a master’s degree in performance 
and a master’s degree in education leading to certifica-
tion. He was coming into his second year in the PhD pro-
gram at the time of the study.
Steve.
 Steve entered the PhD program in the fall of 2009 
after 
7 years teaching elementary through high school 
band. He had completed a master’s degree in a summers-
only program elsewhere and had worked previously with 
Carol as a student in a workshop she had taught. Steve 
was coming into his second year in the PhD program at 
the time of the study.
Issues of Rapport
The previous associations that Carol had with both Elle 
and Steve helped to facilitate the trust needed for faculty 
and students to work together in a self-study environ-
ment. In addition, all three students had worked with 
Carol for two semesters in fall of 2009 and winter of 2010 
so they had experienced the attempt at an equal power 
relationship that Carol tries to work toward (realizing that 
it is not entirely possible within the confines of a univer-
sity structure and with the roles, student and professor).
Data Collection Devices and Procedures
Data included (a) three focus group interviews with Carol 
(the advisor) and the three PhD students (October 10, 
February 11, June 11), (b) self-study journals from all four, 
and (c) individual interviews between Carol and each stu-
dent participant. The focus groups were held at the home of 
one of the PhD student participants and were informal con-
versations about music teaching and learning, PhD student 
growth, and what was helpful or not in the PhD program. 
All focus group interviews were audiorecorded.
Each of the four participants wrote self-study journals 
documenting thoughts and feelings about graduate teach-
ing and other thoughts (personal growth, feedback about 
the curriculum, etc.).

Data Collection Devices and Procedures
Data included (a) three focus group interviews with Carol 
(the advisor) and the three PhD students (October 10, 
February 11, June 11), (b) self-study journals from all four, 
and (c) individual interviews between Carol and each stu-
dent participant. The focus groups were held at the home of 
one of the PhD student participants and were informal con-
versations about music teaching and learning, PhD student 
growth, and what was helpful or not in the PhD program. 
All focus group interviews were audiorecorded.
Each of the four participants wrote self-study journals 
documenting thoughts and feelings about graduate teach-
ing and other thoughts (personal growth, feedback about 
the curriculum, etc.). There was no consistent format and 
each participant chose to write about what worked for 
him or her. Some wrote using bullet points while others 
wrote in prose. Each participant journal was between 900 
and 1,500 words that collectively produced 4,600 journal 
words. Finally, each individual interview lasted approxi-
mately 45 to 60 minutes and was audiorecorded. All par-
ticipants completed institutional review board procedures 
prior to participation in the study.
Analysis and Trustworthiness
Carol completed the first round of coding in the fall of 
2011, and shared her scheme with the PhD student coau-
thors. A trained research assistant from the university’s

Findings and Discussion
In an effort to best capture the reflective process inherent 
in self-study work, each of the three emergent findings 
about PhD students and graduate teaching is described 
through the self-written profiles of each doctoral student 
participant. Profiles are presented alphabetically—Elle, 
Matt, and Steve—each time. Quotation marks are used 
when participants are quoting from their own self-study 
journals or the interview transcripts.
Views of Teaching Graduate Students 
Changed With Increased Experience
There was consistency among the PhD students in sug-
gesting that the more experience they had in teaching 
graduate students, the more comfortable they became. All 
three participants agreed that their views of teaching 
graduate students changed as they had more experience.
Elle.
 I 
did not consciously consider teaching graduate stu-
dents until I began my doctorate, prior to which I believed 
I would return to K–12 instrumental teaching. Once I 
became a doctoral student, I began to think of myself as a 
future professor, but of undergraduates. I had previous 
experiences working with preservice teachers during field-
work or student teaching and because of those experiences 
and my knowledge of teaching within K–12 schools, I felt 
confident of my abilities as a future teacher educator.
“I haven’t had opportunities to think about that, to do 
that [work with graduate students]” (Focus Group, 
October, 2011). In the beginning of our study, I had sev-
eral preconceptions and fears of working with graduate 
students. I felt that graduate instruction was mostly dis-
cussion based, often without any predetermined plan of 
conversation. I worried that I would not know enough 
information to be able to cover every possible area of dis-
cussion and would appear ill equipped to lead the class. 
My worry of “Am I going to know enough” (Focus 
Group, October, 2010) initially affected my collaboration 
with the participants for our Action Research study. After 
our first meeting with the participants, I reflected,
What am I doing here? That is the question that kept going 
through my mind during the entire meeting. I haven’t even 
started my doctorate, which puts me on equal footing with 
our participating teachers. In fact, I felt behind them because 
two of them (I think) had written theses, which gives a pretty 
good feeling for the whole dissertation process. They had 
completed their own studies, and I had not. What am I going 
to contribute? (Journal, August, 2010)
Throughout the study, I observed the manner in which 
my professors interacted with me and delivered content 
in class. I emulated some of these behaviors when I 
worked with the teacher participants from our Action 
Research/Teacher Research study. Midway through the 
study, I started teaching a music technology course at the 
university. In my class of 10, two were master’s students. 
In my effort to tailor the class to serve the needs of all of 
my students, I worked hard to design both undergraduate 
(i.e., skills based) and graduate (i.e., reflective, discus-
sion based) activities. What struck me during this class, 
however, was that my teaching mannerisms (e.g., body 
language, use of questions, and tone of voice) with the 
undergraduates did not feel different from my interac-
tions with the graduate students.
As we conclude our data collection for this self-study, I 
have come to the following conclusions based on my few 
graduate teaching experiences: “There’s an art form to 
teaching graduate students just like there is to teaching any 
other level” (Focus Group, October, 2010). I believe that 
teaching graduate students is different from teaching under-
graduate students, though I think the differences are subtle. 
As in all classes, an instructor’s delivery can influence a 
student’s receptivity of the content matter. I think it is espe-
cially important to acknowledge the existing knowledge of 
graduate students as a symbol of respect and to best help 
them make connections with new material.

my work with the teacher participants in our study as one of

ences, combined with my knowledge of action research 
would, ultimately, expand and strengthen both our insights.
Matt.
 My first opportunity to teach graduate students 
came in summer 2010, when I gave a presentation in the 
curriculum course for the summer master
’s program. I 
recall my initial concerns focused on confidence in know-
ing the literature:
In thinking about my own preparation for teaching a graduate 
class at this stage in my development, I worry that I’m not 
familiar enough with the professional literature. I suppose 
the best way to learn about what I do and do not know is to 
teach a graduate class and jot down questions that arise 
through the discussions we are having. Then I can go back to 
the literature to fill in the gaps. (Journal, July, 2010)
This mind-set indicates my belief in the importance of 
expertise. Over the course of that summer, I was also

invited to give a presentation in the philosophy course 
and the research course, which boosted my confidence in

At an informal gathering at 
the conclusion of the summer session, some of the gradu-
ate students expressed how much they enjoyed my pre-
sentation and they asked if the topics were areas I focused 
on in my research! What a compliment!
After another year of coursework and study of con-
structivist approaches to teaching, I had two more oppor-
tunities to teach in the summer master’s program. Rather 
than viewing my presentations as opportunities to express 
my knowledge of the material (i.e., authoritative 
approach), I began to recognize the value of allowing 
space for students to share their views and knowledge of 
the topic. This allayed fears about an insufficient knowl-
edge base and refocused my mindset on creating a class-
room that values student input and inquiry.
Steve.
 Originally
, teaching graduate students was incred-
ibly intimidating and I equated it with the experience of 
teaching P–12 instrumental music for the first time. As I 
gained more experience teaching graduate (or graduate 
age/level of experience) students, I came to trust myself 
and teach them as adults and not as I would undergradu-
ates. Toward the beginning of my graduate teaching 
experiences I felt intimidated by their age and experi-
ence: “These teachers have a lot of expertise and the 
thought of ‘who am I to offer them advice’ came up in my 
mind” (Journal, October, 2010). As I progressed, I real-
ized their age and experience affected how I designed my 
lessons and how I interacted with them; I began to see 
their experience as a strength and less as an intimidator. I 
related this experience to how I progressed teaching 
undergraduate students: “With undergraduates I feel like 
I teach them the ‘what,’ with the graduates I’m exploring 
the ‘how’ and the ‘why’ and relying on what they are 
bringing to the table” (Individual Interview, July, 2011).
I started designing my graduate teaching experiences 
relying on what was comfortable (teaching undergradu-
ates and P–12) and what was modeled for me (college 
professors). As I gained experience I realized that what I 
design for graduates to do in class and how I approach 
them did change.
I’m going to go back to my comfort zone, which is how I 
would teach an undergrad class, and adjust things from 
there. . . . I’m going to draw on my success in teaching 
undergrad classes, but draw on my experiences teaching 
these little graduate units and try to meld the two. (Individual 
Interview, July, 2011)
I incorporated more interactive activities, focused more 
on what they bring to the classroom and less on a pre-
scribed curriculum. “I realized the power of engaging 
them to talk to each other. Tapping into their prior experi-
ence is what made the session fly!” (Journal, June, 2011).
Confidence Increased With More Experience 
Teaching Graduate Classes and With More 
Time to Process the Graduate “Content”
Elle. I still worry about knowing enough material to 
effectively work with graduate students. Am I studying 
the 
“right” subjects? Is my education diverse enough? As 
I have come to realize over the course of this project, I 
feel comfortable working with graduate students when I 
feel comfortable with the content. I am more comfortable 
teaching the content covered in an undergraduate degree 
because I have taught it and know it well. However, I also 
felt comfortable leading a summer workshop of graduate 
students and veteran teachers because I knew the content. 
Because I was confident with the subject matter, I was 
able to relinquish class control, I was comfortable facili-
tating discussion and asking my students to share their 
ideas and past successes. Leading the workshop was fun, 
stimulating, and a boost to my self-confidence. The entire 
time, it felt like teaching. Not teaching graduate students, 
just teaching. To this, I attribute my comfort with the sub-
ject matter.
Matt.
 I 
believe my self-efficacy has increased with each 
opportunity I’ve had to try different teaching strategies 
and to reflect on their effectiveness. My initial presenta-
tion in July, 2010 was primarily lecture, which limited the 
graduate students (i.e., fellow teachers enrolled in sum-
mer coursework) from discussing their experiences in 
their classrooms.

believe my self-efficacy has increased with each

I went into [Carol’s summer 2011 class] thinking of it more

Steve. This was a huge issue for me to overcome. When I 
had my first few experiences teaching graduate students, 
I strongly doubted my abilities to offer them anything: “I 
questioned my ability to offer them relevant and useful 
material” (Journal, July, 2011); “I questioned what I 
could offer them” (Journal, July, 2010); “The fact that 
they were paying me affected my nerves” (Journal, June, 
2011). As I gained more experience and received positive 
feedback from both graduate students and the professors 
whose classes I was teaching, my confidence grew:

The Most Useful Activities Were Those That 
Went Beyond “One Shot”
Elle. Aside from teaching the technology course and the 
summer workshop, I have only had “one shot” experi
-
ences working with graduate classes. This summer, I was 
a guest in the summer master’s beginning research class. 
I presented an overview of how to locate research sources, 
leading students through various computer search engines 
and citation software. Although I appreciated the experi-
ence of being a “guest lecturer” in a graduate class, I did 
not feel that I was really teaching. Instead, my presenta-
tion felt like I was showing a colleague or my technology 
students how to use a computer. Perhaps I felt this way 
because when I was a student in beginning research, I 
learned how to locate materials from a librarian who vis-
ited our class. I also wonder if it is because the content 
did not feel like what I envisioned myself teaching to 
graduate students. I wonder if I would have felt similarly 
if I presented on, for example, research methodologies or 
learning styles.
Matt.
 Just as a conductor must practice in front of the 
ensemble to improve his or her interactions with the 
ensemble, practicing teaching is necessary to gain confi
-
dence, increase self-efficacy, and improve one’s teaching 
ability. It is hard to chart one’s growth as a teacher of 
graduate students without successive teaching opportuni-
ties. I found that each time I worked with the same group 
of students in the summer master’s program, my teaching 
improved because I was more familiar with each stu-
dent’s background, interests, and experience. As a result, 
I could better situate discussion prompts, focus on areas 
they were interested in, or work with those needing more 
attention.
Steve.
 There are two levels that I felt this finding
 
addressed—(a) working with students more than once, and 
(b) teaching the material more than once. For both, the 
more I taught, the better I felt I did, the less nervous I was, 
and the better the participant comments were. As for teach-
ing students more than once, I felt having a prior relation-
ship helped subsequent classes. “The more I interacted 
with the students the better relationships I had, the more I 
interacted with the material, the more confident I was” 
(Individual Interview, July, 2011). “I knew the students and 
was able to play off of the prior experience” (Journal, July, 
2011); “It helped to have a previous social interaction with 
them” (Journal, July, 2010). “If nothing else, I was able to 
dovetail on the previous interactions” (Individual Inter-
view, July, 2011). In terms of the material, the more I 
taught it, the better I was at being aware to the class and 
less on my presentation. “Instead of a random ‘guest’ I felt 
that I offered valued information for them that tied into the 
topics they were already discussing” (Focus Group, July, 
2010); “I focused on their expertise” (Journal, June, 2011).
Discussion
The profiles presented here have led us to suggest three 
conclusions in relation to how these PhD student partici-
pants considered their preparation for graduate teaching. 
First, it is important to recognize that learning to teach 
graduate students was a developmental process just as has 
been suggested on teaching preservice students (Conway 
et
 al., 
2010). With more experience came more success. 
Although these participants did not always have control 
over their schedules, it was important to find time within 
the graduate program for more reflection on content. It 
appears from this study that comfort with the music edu-
cation content was a strong predictor of feelings of suc-
cess in graduate teaching.

Discussion
The profiles presented here have led us to suggest three 
conclusions in relation to how these PhD student partici-
pants considered their preparation for graduate teaching. 
First, it is important to recognize that learning to teach 
graduate students was a developmental process just as has 
been suggested on teaching preservice students (Conway 
et
 al., 
2010). With more experience came more success. 
Although these participants did not always have control 
over their schedules, it was important to find time within 
the graduate program for more reflection on content. It 
appears from this study that comfort with the music edu-
cation content was a strong predictor of feelings of suc-
cess in graduate teaching. Having opportunities for 
teaching the content in graduate courses or leading class 
discussions on content was an important part of develop-
ing self-efficacy, confidence, and professorial identity. 
Students (and the faculty advising the graduate programs) 
may benefit from being intentional about preparation for 
graduate teaching; be purposeful about seeking (or creat-
ing, in the case of faculty) opportunities for PhD students 
to hone their skills as teachers of graduate students.
Conclusion
I (Carol) feel that asking the doctoral students for help 
and seeing the program through their eyes as suggested 
by Walker et
 
al. (2008) has led to some helpful feedback 
for the doctoral program at the university. Although 
Elle, Steve, and Matt have now all left campus to con-
tinue on with their professional careers, I continue to try 
to do more of the mentoring and graduate preparation 
that was helpful to them with the new crop of graduate 
students. I would encourage other self-study researchers 
to explore graduate education through self-study so we 
can begin to build theories and understanding of the 
growth of these scholars at such an important time in 
their development.

Being able to effectively regulate study is an essential 
part of the educational experience. Indeed, it is plau-
sible that as much, if not more, learning takes place 
outside the classroom as inside the classroom. As a 
result, equipping students with effective study strategies 
is vital to their educational success. Fortunately, recent 
interest in applying cognitive principles to enhance 
educational practices has produced a substantial litera-
ture on effective study strategies. A number of reviews 
have been published on empirically supported tech-
niques by both cognitive and educational psychologists 
(Dunlosky, Rawson, Marsh, Nathan, & Willingham, 
2013; Fiorella & Mayer, 2015; Mayer, 2008; Roediger & 
Pyc, 2012). Thus, the good news is that there are potent 
study strategies that can help students learn more effi-
caciously. The bad news, however, is that students do 
not often use the learning strategies that cognitive 
researchers have identified as being effective (Hartwig 
& Dunlosky, 2012; Karpicke, Butler, & Roediger, 2009; 
Kornell & Bjork, 2007; Wissman, Rawson, & Pyc, 2012; 
Yan, Thai, & Bjork, 2014). Self-report questionnaires 
typically find that students are not aware of the effec-
tiveness of potent evidence-based study strategies and 
thus do not regularly implement them (McCabe, 2011). 
In addition, empirical studies suggest that students seek 
conditions that maximize their perceived understanding 
of the material at the moment of study rather than 
conditions that maximize their learning as indexed by 
later test results (for additional discussion on the distinc-
tion between performance and learning, see Soderstrom 
& Bjork, 2015). That is, students want to see rapid gains 
when they are studying and erroneously take these 
gains as actual understanding, thus preferring whatever 
study strategies support rapid gains.
Students appear to hold strong preferences for study 
techniques that they have used throughout their edu-
cational careers; consequently, attempts to sell them on 
new strategies may be met with resistance. Accordingly, 
we suggest that a fruitful alternative approach is to 
examine the effectiveness of the study strategies that 
students regularly implement and identify ways to aug-
ment these preferred study strategies. As a first step, 
we review the empirical evidence on the effectiveness 
of the study strategies that students actually use. An

Five Popular Study Strategies: Their  
Pitfalls and Optimal Implementations
Toshiya Miyatsu, Khuyen Nguyen, and Mark A. McDaniel
Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences, Washington University in St. Louis
Abstract
Researchers’ and educators’ enthusiasm in applying cognitive principles to enhance educational practices has become 
more evident. Several published reviews have suggested that some potent strategies can help students learn more 
efficaciously. Unfortunately, for whatever reason, students do not report frequent reliance on these empirically supported 
techniques. In the present review, we take a novel approach, identifying study strategies for which students have strong 
preferences and assessing whether these preferred strategies have any merit given existing empirical evidence from the 
cognitive and educational literatures. Furthermore, we provide concrete recommendations for students, instructors, and 
psychologists. For students, we identify common pitfalls and tips for optimal implementation for each study strategy. 
For instructors, we provide recommendations for how they can assist students to more optimally implement these study 
strategies. For psychologists, we highlight promising avenues of research to help augment these study strategies.
Keywords
study strategies, self-regulated learning, education

Five Popular Study Strategies 391
examination of students’ self-reported study strategies 
yielded five popular strategies that students routinely 
prefer: (a) rereading, (b) highlighting or underlining, (c) 
note-taking, (d) outlining, and (e) using flash cards 
(Hartwig & Dunlosky, 2012; Karpicke et al., 2009; Kornell 
& Bjork, 2007; Wissman et al., 2012; Yan et al., 2014); 
casual observation on any college campus confirms 
these findings (for a summary of the frequency of use 
of these top five strategies, see Table 1).
Although a couple of these strategies (i.e., rereading 
and highlighting or underlining) have been reviewed 
elsewhere, they have typically been assessed relative to 
more effective strategies. For instance, Dunlosky et al. 
(2013) gave rereading and highlighting or underlining 
a low utility rating relative to other more potent tech-
niques, such as testing and spaced practice. To a casual 
reader, this overall assessment suggests that rereading 
and highlighting or underlining should not be used in 
any educational context. Furthermore, because Dunlosky 
et al. focused on the general utility of these study strate-
gies, they might have overlooked the possibility that 
these study strategies may be particularly effective (or 
commonly misused) in certain situations. Thus, less 
emphasis has been placed on how effective these strate-
gies are relative to no study strategy. All five of the 
popular study strategies being reviewed here can be 
potent when properly used. Thus, a primary purpose 
of the present review is to emphasize the conditions 
under which these popular techniques do and do not 
foster effective learning and highlight ways in which 
they can be precisely prescribed.
We will cover each study strategy in turn, and each 
study-strategy section is organized into three subsec-
tions: effective implementations, ineffective implementa-
tions, and educational recommendations . We anticipate 
that this review will be beneficial for a wide audience, 
including students, educators, and psychologists. For 
students and educators, this review will shed some light 
on how and when these popular study strategies should 
be implemented to get the most from students’ study 
time. With this purpose in mind, the Introduction and 
the Educational Recommendation subsections of each 
of the five sections are written with minimal technical 
terminology. For psychologists, our hope is that this 
review will create excitement about new lines of 
research on study strategies that are both theoretically 
interesting and—perhaps more important—educationally 
motivated.
Rereading
A straightforward assumption is that rereading texts 
should yield benefits of repetition similar to that gener-
ally found in list-learning experiments (i.e., multiple 
exposures of words lead to better recall than a single 
exposure; e.g., Tulving, 1966; but for an interesting 
exception, see Mulligan & Peterson, 2015). Yet this 
assumption has not been investigated as extensively as 
one would imagine, given the popularity of rereading 
as a study strategy (e.g., Karpicke et al., 2009). Since 
the 1970s, cognitive and educational psychologists have 
typically endorsed study strategies that require active 
processing of complex materials such as texts (Segal, 
Chipman, & Glaser, 1985; Weinstein, Goetz, & Alexander, 
1988; Wittrock, 1974). Thus, research on rereading has 
often taken a backseat to research focusing on more 
active study strategies because rereading may be pas-
sive in nature, at least in the manner in which students 
do it (for a different perspective based on laboratory 
studies, see Stine-Morrow, Gagne, Morrow, & DeWall, 
2004). We posit that this may be the same reason why 
rereading is so popular among students. Because 
rereading does not necessarily require active and effort-
ful processing of the text, it gives students the (false) 
sense that they are effectively learning the text (Roediger 
& Karpicke, 2006b; although see Rawson, Dunlosky, & 
Thiede, 2000). That is, the second reading of a text feels 
more fluent than the first reading, and the increased 
fluency is perceived by students, accurately or inac-
curately, as an indication of successful learning (Rawson 
& Dunlosky, 2002).

more fluent than the first reading, and the increased 
fluency is perceived by students, accurately or inac-
curately, as an indication of successful learning (Rawson 
& Dunlosky, 2002). Nevertheless, as highlighted next, 
under certain conditions, rereading can benefit memory 
and comprehension.
Effective implementation
Rereading is particularly effective when the first and 
second readings are spaced out. A plethora of research

392 Miyatsu et al.
in the verbal-learning literature has shown that spaced 
study (i.e., an intervening lag between study opportuni-
ties) produces superior memory performance relative 
to massed study (i.e., no intervening lag between study 
opportunities; for a recent review, see Cepeda, Pashler, 
Vul, Wixted, & Rohrer, 2006). In addition, this finding 
has been extended to text materials. For instance, 
Glover and Corkill (1987) had students read short para-
graphs twice with either an immediate lag (massed 
group) or a 30-min lag (spaced group). They found that 
the spaced group was able to recall more of the content 
than the massed group on an immediate free-recall test 
(see also Krug, Davis, & Glover, 1990). However, Verkoeijen, 
Rikers, and Ozsoy (2008) found that too much spacing can 
be detrimental for text learning. Specifically, they com-
pared a massed reread group with both a shorter-spaced 
reread group (i.e., 4 days) and a longer-spaced reread 
group (i.e., 3.5 weeks) and found that only the shorter-
spaced reread group outperformed the massed reread 
group on a free-recall test after a 48-hr delay. The longer-
spaced reread group was only able to recall as many 
details as the massed reread group, which suggests that 
the benefits of spacing diminish when the lag is too long.
To determine an optimal lag between the first and 
second readings, one must consider the retention inter -
val. To this end, Rawson and Kintsch (2005) imple-
mented a factorial design manipulating both lag and 
retention interval in four conditions: (a) immediate lag 
and immediate retention interval, (b) immediate lag and 
delayed retention interval, (c) long lag and immediate 
retention interval, and (d) long lag and delayed reten-
tion interval (see also Rawson, 2012). Their results indi-
cated that long lags with a delayed retention interval 
benefited test performance (relative to a single read-
ing), but long lags with an immediate retention interval 
yielded no benefits. Instead, with an immediate reten-
tion interval, the immediate lag but not the long lag 
condition yielded superior performance relative to a 
single reading. These results suggest that long lags 
between reading opportunities are vital for producing 
more durable learning (i.e., performance on delayed 
tests) relative to a single reading. However, under cer-
tain conditions (e.g., immediate tests), massed reread-
ing may actually be more beneficial than spaced 
rereading.1
Ineffective implementation
As we have discussed above, spacing out the first and 
second readings is beneficial for long-term retention of 
the studied information. On the flip side, massing the 
readings (or cramming) has been shown to produce 
limited benefits (Rawson, 2012; Rawson & Kintsch, 
2005). Unless the test is going to take place immediately 
after the second reading (which is unlikely in educa-
tional settings), it is not recommended that students 
engage in massed rereading.
Furthermore, although rereading has been shown to 
produce robust benefits for free recall and cued-recall 
tests (particularly if the readings are spaced apart), its 
benefits for higher order assessments (e.g., application-
based, inference-based, or problem-solving tests) are 
less clear. Callender and McDaniel (2009) had partici-
pants read authentic textbook chapters either once or 
twice and found that (relative to a single reading) 
rereading did not improve performance on short-
answer application questions or summary writing. How-
ever, Karpicke and Blunt (2011) compared groups that 
had different numbers of reading opportunities (i.e., 
one or four) and found that rereading enhanced per-
formance for inference multiple-choice and short-
answer application tests relative to a single reading. It 
is important to note that participants in the Karpicke 
and Blunt study were allowed to restudy the passage 
four times, and the passages were much shorter (i.e., 
approximately 300 words) than those typically assigned 
in college classes. As a result, the Karpicke and Blunt 
study may not have captured the complexity of typical 
text comprehension at the college level.

and Blunt study were allowed to restudy the passage

approximately 300 words) than those typically assigned 
in college classes. As a result, the Karpicke and Blunt 
study may not have captured the complexity of typical
