the stimuli present within a situation, individuals respond to present
stimuli and engage in crime as a result of a matching function“… in
which the behavior most frequently, probably, and highly reinforced is
chosen and performed to the exclusion of all other alternatives” (Akers,
2009:69). Should this matching function output a criminal behavior,
then a criminal behavior will be enacted.
It is important to note that the model of social learning theory
presented in Fig. 1 represents a localized version of the theory that
emphasizes one's learning history prior to encountering a criminogenic
situation, as well as how the products of one's learning history— one's
deﬁnitions— produce criminal behavior within the situation at hand. In
doing so, the model neglects a full representation of the theory that
would necessarily include various reciprocal and feedback eﬀects that
occur continuously throughout one's life as would be present in a pro-
cessual representation of the theory. We present this localized version
of the theory instead in order to clearly identify the location in the
theory where recent critics of the theory have focused their attention.
3. Recent criticisms of social learning theory
Over the last twenty years, social learning theory has experienced
renewed criticisms relating to empirical tests of the theory (for a re-
view, seeBrauer & Tittle, 2012). For this paper, however, two criticisms
are particularly important: (1) the mechanisms of learning proposed by
the theory have not been empirically assessed; and (2) conceptual
problems exist in which concepts are not adequately diﬀerentiated from
one another.
3.1. Lack of empirical support
Despite claims that social learning theory possesses strong empirical
support (e.g.,Akers, 2009), critics counter that few empirical tests have
actually examined the theory's primary causal mechanisms: operant
conditioning and vicarious reinforcement (e.g.,Brauer, 2009; Brauer &
Tittle, 2012; Krohn, 1999; Rebellon, 2006; Sampson, 1999). Moreover,
a meta-analysis of social learning theory byPratt et al. (2010)found
that those studies that do empirically examine these learning mechan-
ismsﬁnd weak or insigniﬁcant results. According to critics, the lack of
empirical evidence supporting social learning theory's learning me-
chanisms is a consequence of: (1) an absence of longitudinal research
capable of observing the operant conditioning mechanism (Brauer &
Tittle, 2012; Rebellon, 2006); (2) criminologists preferring to examine
diﬀerential associations and crime over direct tests of learning me-
chanisms because of the strength of this relationship (Rebellon, 2006);
(3) the diﬃculty in directly observing learning mechanisms (Brauer,
2009); and/or (4) the paucity of secondary data that contain direct
measures of reinforcements (Brauer & Tittle, 2012). Regardless of the
reason, the general consensus of critics is that little empirical support
exists for social learning theory's claim that reinforcement is a key
mechanism involved in criminal behavior.
As further noted by social learning theory's critics, this failure to
directly measure reinforcement mechanisms leaves the theory left with
but a handful of concepts— peers/diﬀerential associations and deﬁni-
tions— to explain crime, none of which are unique to social learning
theory. Thus, a secondary outcome stemming from the absence of direct
empirical support for social learning theory's reinforcement mechanism
is that any empirical support for social learning theory could also be
seen as providing support for the many other theories that also draw
upon these concepts (Brauer & Tittle, 2012; Gottfredson & Hirschi,
1990; Sampson, 1999).
3.2. Lack of conceptual diﬀerentiation or clarity
The second criticism of social learning theory relevant to this paper
is the claim that social learning theory does not deﬁne its concepts
clearly enough to diﬀerentiate adequately between them. Speciﬁcally,
critics argue that social learning theory: (1) treats reinforcements and
anticipated reinforcements as the same phenomenon; and (2) fails to
reconcile how verbal cues or instructions square with behaviorist
principles.

Thus, a secondary outcome stemming from the absence of direct
empirical support for social learning theory's reinforcement mechanism
is that any empirical support for social learning theory could also be
seen as providing support for the many other theories that also draw
upon these concepts (Brauer & Tittle, 2012; Gottfredson & Hirschi,
1990; Sampson, 1999).
3.2. Lack of conceptual diﬀerentiation or clarity
The second criticism of social learning theory relevant to this paper
is the claim that social learning theory does not deﬁne its concepts
clearly enough to diﬀerentiate adequately between them. Speciﬁcally,
critics argue that social learning theory: (1) treats reinforcements and
anticipated reinforcements as the same phenomenon; and (2) fails to
reconcile how verbal cues or instructions square with behaviorist
principles. The ﬁrst criticism highlights that reinforcements should be
conceptually distinguished from anticipated reinforcements since re-
inforcement pertains to learning, and anticipated reinforcements are a
product of learning (Brauer, 2009; Brauer & Tittle, 2012).
The second criticism relates to social learning theory's lack of
clarity; that is, how the theory fails to reconcile how verbal cues or
instructions square with behaviorist principles. As noted byBrauer and
Tittle (2012), much experimental literature in behavioral analysis in-
volves alternative forms of learning that might involve verbal instruc-
tions or repetition. Because experimental studies often take for granted
that operant conditioning plays a role in learning, operant conditioning
mechanisms are not actually measured. As such, it remains unclear
whether operant conditioning or another possible form of learning is
occurring in the investigation.
4. Retroﬁtting social learning theory
A signiﬁcant shortcoming of the previous criticisms is the taken for
granted assumption that operant conditioning and/or vicarious re-
inforcement are actually the primary mechanisms whereby criminal
behavior is learned (cf:Brauer & Tittle, 2012), let alone whether re-
inforcement-based forms of learning are congruent with modern un-
derstandings of learning present within cognitive psychology and
Fig. 1.Basic model of social learning theory.
K.R. Proctor and R.E. Niemeyer Journal of Criminal Justice xxx (xxxx) xxxx
2

neuroscience. As noted byProctor and Niemeyer (2019), social learning
theory's conception of learning is antiquated as a consequence of its
reliance on behaviorism, S-R-S chains, and black boxing of the brain
and mind. Central to Proctor and Niemeyer's claim is that social
learning theory curiously omits any discussion of memory or the neu-
roanatomy and physiology of learning and memory, two areas where
profound scientiﬁc discoveries have occurred in cognitive psychology
and neuroscience over the lastﬁfty years.
This description of social learning theory might appear somewhat at
odds with elaborations of the theory which havesubstantively moved
the theory away from the strict form of behaviorism present in the
theory's original statement byBurgess and Akers (1966). As noted by
Akers (2009), the original statement of the theory in the form of dif-
ferential association-reinforcement theory relied on an orthodox inter-
pretation of behaviorism that eschewed mental or cognitive phe-
nomena. Later elaborations of the theory reemphasized the theory's
roots within symbolic interactionism and represented a form of social
behaviorism that reattended to the signiﬁcance of cognitions in its ex-
planation of crime, which meant the theory was more congruent with
the social learning theory of Bandura than the radical behaviorism of
Skinner (Akers, 2009).
While Akers' version of social learning theory broke with radical
behaviorism in regard to its substance, this break did not reﬂect a
complete departure from behaviorism's failure to recognize the etiolo-
gical role of the central nervous or its properties or characteristics in
regard to behavior. Thus, while behaviorism's black box was opened to
allow the presence of cognitions in the form of deﬁnitions in social
learning theory's explanations of crime, deﬁnitions themselves were
treated as discriminative stimuli (Akers, 2009) that were not tied to any
underlying neurological foundation. Consequently, the elaborated form
of social learning theory explained the activities involved in learning
(i.e., S-R-S chains) and the content of what was learned (i.e., deﬁni-
tions) but did not illuminate the black box of the mind in terms of how
cognitions might be stored in memory, as well as the neuroanatomy and
physiology involved in forming memories.
Social learning theory's continued reliance on behaviorism in this
regard has meant the theory focuses on the behavioral activities in-
volved in learning and ignores the properties or characteristics of the
central nervous system that in ﬂuence the learning processes and
memory. As noted byTerry (2016), throughout the twentieth century,
behaviorists were primarily concerned with learning as an activity,
which they conceived in terms of conditioning and reinforcement. The
concept of memory was examined separately within cognitive psy-
chology and therefore neglected by behaviorism (Terry, 2016). Conse-
quently, behaviorism was unconcerned with how learning related to
retention of the things learned, and this omission of discussions of
memory remains within the contemporary statement of social learning
theory.
To address the criticisms of social learning theory that have been
summarized thus far, we contend the theory must: (1) incorporate
contemporary understandings of learning and memory; and (2)
abandon behaviorism as an underlying paradigm.
4.1. Contemporary understandings of learning and memory
The basic learning model within social learning theory has become
outmoded compared to understandings of learning and memory present
within cognitive psychology and neuroscience. Within these ﬁelds,
learning is “the process of acquiring new and relatively enduring in-
formation, behavior patterns, or abilities, characterized by modiﬁca-
tions of behavior as a result of practice, study, or experience ”
(Breedlove & Watson, 2013:512). Memory is typically deﬁned as either:
(1) the ability to retain and retrieve information, behavior patterns, or
abilities
across some interval of time, or (2) the actual information,
behavior patterns, or abilities stored within the brain (Terry, 2016).
Critical to addressing critics of social learning theory, though, is the fact
that numerous forms of memory have been discovered to exist, with
each possessing its own unique productive mechanisms.

Within these ﬁelds,
learning is “the process of acquiring new and relatively enduring in-
formation, behavior patterns, or abilities, characterized by modiﬁca-
tions of behavior as a result of practice, study, or experience ”
(Breedlove & Watson, 2013:512). Memory is typically deﬁned as either:
(1) the ability to retain and retrieve information, behavior patterns, or
abilities
across some interval of time, or (2) the actual information,
behavior patterns, or abilities stored within the brain (Terry, 2016).
Critical to addressing critics of social learning theory, though, is the fact
that numerous forms of memory have been discovered to exist, with
each possessing its own unique productive mechanisms.
Cognitive psychology and neuroscience currently distinguish be-
tween two main types of memory — nondeclarative and declarative
memory— with each having various subtypes of memory. It is important
to note that various forms of learning and memory can co-occur; thus,
the presence of one form of learning and memory can aﬀect the me-
chanisms that generate other forms of learning and memory (Jeansok &
Baxter, 2001). Due to space constraints, we limit our discussions of
nondeclarative and declarative memory to those forms that directly
relate to the current statement of social learning theory.
4.1.1. Nondeclarative memory
Within cognitive psychology and neuroscience, nondeclarative
memory is a class of memory that isnot consciously accessible to in-
dividuals. Regarding social learning theory, two types of nondeclarative
memory are particularly important: skills and conditioned behaviors.
4.1.1.1. Skills. Skills are a form of memory that enable individuals to
deliberately interact with their environments to produce a desired
change (Gluck, Mercado, & Myers, 2016;Rudy, 2014). Thus, skills are
instrumental. Skills include cognitive skills, motor skills, and visual-
motor skills. Cognitive skills reﬂect the ability to hold and manipulate
large quantities of information (Terry, 2016), motor skills enable one
engage in precise muscle movements (Kellogg, 2016), and visual-motor
skills relate to motors skills that are directed by sensory inputs (Gluck
et al., 2016:312). Two types of skills— actions and habits— have been
identiﬁed by cognitive psychologists and neuroscientists (Rudy, 2014).
Although actions and habits are learned and deployed using diﬀerent
neural systems and often compete with one another during behavioral
tasks, research clearly shows actions and habits do often operate in
tandem to allow for complex forms of behavior (Kool, Cushman, &
Gershman, 2018; Wood & Rünger, 2016).
Actions are comprised of a consciously present goal that is deliber-
ately pursued through a course of behavior believed to achieve the
desired goal. Generally speaking, actions are characterized by three
properties: (1) teleological determination; (2) conscious selection; and
(3) cognitive oversight ( Dolan & Dayan, 2013 ). Actions are tele-
ologically determined in that the presence of a desired goal determines
their content and structure. Actions are consciously selected in that they
are deliberately chosen based upon preexisting knowledge about which
behaviors are likely to be eﬀective for attaining the desired goal. In
humans, this preexisting knowledge, which is commonly referred to as
an internal model (Doll, Duncan, Simon, Shohamy, & Daw, 2015), can
stem from previous conditioned learning and/or reinforcement
learning, as well as from deliberately recalled personal experience (i.e.,
episodic memory), and/or symbolic knowledge related to the goal (i.e.,
semantic memory) (Behrens et al., 2018; Gershman & Daw, 2017;
Radulescu, Niv, & Ballard, 2019). Actions are consciously monitored to
the
degree that the outcomes resulting from the performed actions are
deliberately compared to the expected outcome generated by the se-
lected model (Dezfouli & Balleine, 2013; Dolan & Dayan, 2013).
The neural mechanism underlying cognitive oversight is called the
action system and is comprised of the prefrontal cortex, sensory sys-
tems, association areas that combine various sensory inputs, motor
areas, the cerebellum, the basal ganglia, and the spinal cord.

Actions are consciously monitored to
the
degree that the outcomes resulting from the performed actions are
deliberately compared to the expected outcome generated by the se-
lected model (Dezfouli & Balleine, 2013; Dolan & Dayan, 2013).
The neural mechanism underlying cognitive oversight is called the
action system and is comprised of the prefrontal cortex, sensory sys-
tems, association areas that combine various sensory inputs, motor
areas, the cerebellum, the basal ganglia, and the spinal cord. Within this
system, the internal model comprising an individual's present needs, the
goals thought to satisfy them, the norms and criteria that govern how
actions should be executed, and information about the spatial re-
lationships present between an individual's body and nearby objects are
all queued and maintained by the prefrontal cortex as working memory
(A. G. E.Collins & Frank, 2012;Freberg, 2016; Garrett, 2015).
In the case of motor skills, for example, the prefrontal cortex and
supplemental motor area create a concrete motor plan by combining
the internal model stored in working memory with the speciﬁc motor
sequences required to generate the desired outcome (Freberg, 2016;
K.R. Proctor and R.E. Niemeyer Journal of Criminal Justice xxx (xxxx) xxxx
3

Garrett, 2015;Hoshi, 2008). The basal ganglia then evaluates the motor
plan for its appropriateness to the situation (Freberg, 2016; Garrett,
2015). Should the motor plan be deemed appropriate, the basal ganglia
suppresses alternate motor plans and releases the appropriate motor
plan to the primary motor cortex, which then releases a signal to enact
the plan to the spinal cord. The spinal cord then releases the signal to
the muscles, which then directly enact the motor plan. Within this
mechanism, the cerebellum prepares other parts of a person's body to
assist in executing the action (e.g., maintaining one's visual focus on the
object with which one is interacting).
Once a motor plan is enacted, the action system examines sensory
feedback to determine if the expected outcome occurred as predicted by
the internal model. If the expected outcome did occur, the enacted
motor plan is reinforced and is more likely to be enacted in the future
under similar conditions. Should the motor plan fail, the resulting
prediction error will motivate a person to consciously try to identify the
source of the failure and generate a new motor plan based upon a new
mental model.
The internal model and the conscious monitoring of actions should
not be confused with the cognitive skills, motor skills, and visual-motor
skills themselves. Whereas cognitive oversight is a deliberate and con-
scious process, the actual skills involved in an action are a form of
nondeclarative memory that are produced through operant con-
ditioning.
Operant conditioning involves a three-way association and temporal
sequence between a discriminative stimulus, a response, and an out-
come (Gluck et al., 2016:172). Within this sequence, discriminative
stimuli signal to an individual that a particular response will likely
result in the achievement of a goal. Following one's exposure to dis-
criminant stimuli, the individual selects a response to employ in pursuit
of a goal and enacts it. Lastly, the outcome of one's response serves as
either a reward when the goal is attained or a punishment when the
goal is not attained. Responses that are rewarded are more likely to be
enacted in future encounters involving the same goal and discriminant
stimuli, while responses that are punished are less likely to be enacted
under conditions similar to the original situation. Despite the conscious
elements present within an action surrounding need states, goals that
satisfy need states, expected rewards, and the potential presence of
norms that might inﬂuence action selection, the particular skills in-
volved in an action are stored within memory as motor plans located in
the motor areas of the brain and cannot be consciously manipulated or
accessed, which is why actions are considered a nondeclarative form of
memory (Gluck et al., 2016).
If an action is repeatedly and consistently rewarded within the
presence of the same discriminant stimuli in relation to a goal, the
speciﬁc set of behaviors employed in the teleological pursuit of a goal
become fused together into a single form of memory— a habit. Habits
cause speciﬁc actions to automatically occur and execute until com-
pletion when a person encounters discriminant stimuli that were pre-
sent within past situations where a goal was repeatedly achieved (Rudy,
2014).
The habitual behavior enacted in relation to habits possesses two
characteristics that distinguish it from actions. First, habitual behaviors
are triggered mainly in response to the presence of discriminate stimuli
within a situation (Neal, Wood, Labrecque, & Lally, 2012). They are not
guided by goals, and therefore cannot be seen as being deliberate or
intentional. For this reason, habits are also referred to as model-free
(Doll et al., 2015). Second, habits are enacted without regard to the
reinforcement values of their outcomes ( Gluck et al., 2016; Rudy,
2014). Habitual behavior occurs regardless of whether an outcome is
rewarded, punished, or neutral in its reinforcement value (for a review,
see W.Wood & Rünger, 2016). Further, the mechanisms involved in
actions and habitual behavior possess diﬀerences in the way subregions
of the basal ganglia interact with subregions of the frontal cortex
(Adachi & Willoughby, 2011; Ashby, Turner, & Horvitz, 2010;
Lanciego,
Luquin, & Obeso, 2012).
4.1.1.2. Conditioned behaviors .

For this reason, habits are also referred to as model-free
(Doll et al., 2015). Second, habits are enacted without regard to the
reinforcement values of their outcomes ( Gluck et al., 2016; Rudy,
2014). Habitual behavior occurs regardless of whether an outcome is
rewarded, punished, or neutral in its reinforcement value (for a review,
see W.Wood & Rünger, 2016). Further, the mechanisms involved in
actions and habitual behavior possess diﬀerences in the way subregions
of the basal ganglia interact with subregions of the frontal cortex
(Adachi & Willoughby, 2011; Ashby, Turner, & Horvitz, 2010;
Lanciego,
Luquin, & Obeso, 2012).
4.1.1.2. Conditioned behaviors . Conditioned behavior refers to the
retained and retrievable patterns of behavior that are acquired/
learned through the classical conditioning process. As a form of
nondeclarative memory, conditioned behavior is not consciously
accessible to actors. However, unlike operant behavior, which requires
an organism to engage with the environment actively for learning to
occur, conditioned behavior is learned passively. In other words, an
organism does not need toact upon the environment for learning to
occur. Instead, the organism need only be exposed to contingently
paired stimuli in order for a conditioned behavior to form. The exact
regions of the brain involved in the mechanism of classical conditioning
vary depending upon the nature of the stimuli involved. Nonetheless,
they generally include various sensory cortices, the hypothalamus, the
thalamus, the amygdala, the cerebellum, and the brainstem
(Fredrikson, Wik, Fischer, & Andersson, 1995 ; Kim & Jung, 2006;
Squire & Dede, 2015).
Conditioned behavior and the classical conditioning process were
discovered by the Russian physiologist, Ivan Pavlov, as a part of his
research on the causes and consequences of salivation during digestion
in dogs (Todes, 1997). Stated in simple terms, classical conditioning is
the process by which an otherwise insigniﬁcant stimulus automatically
becomes meaningful to an organism over time as the organism re-
peatedly experiences the insigniﬁcant stimulus in conjunction with a
second stimulus that the organism already ﬁnds meaningful. Within
classical conditioning, a stimulus is deﬁned as any object or environ-
mental event, whether it be internal or external to the organism, that
elicits a response (Lefrançois, 2012). A response is deﬁned as any ex-
ternally visible and highly coordinated pattern of sensory, muscular,
glandular, neural, and endocrine activity that occurs as a consequence
of being exposed to a stimulus (Lefrançois, 2012; Levitis, Lidicker, &
Freund, 2009). An insigniﬁcant stimulus, in turn, is any stimulus that
does not normally elicit a speciﬁc set of patterned of responses— other
than, perhaps, gaining the organism's attention— while a meaningful
stimulus is one that does elicit a set of stereotypical responses
(Lefrançois, 2012).
Within the classical conditioning framework, insigniﬁcant stimuli
are called neutral stimuli, and meaningful stimuli are called uncondi-
tioned stimuli. Initially, Pavlov used the Russian word for unconditional
to describe unconditioned stimuli because of the stimuli's ability to
unconditionally elicit the associated set of patterned responses (Todes,
2014). Likewise, Pavlov called the set of responses associated with
unconditioned stimuli unconditional responses because the responses
unconditionally resulted from the organism's exposure to the uncondi-
tional
stimulus. Building upon Pavlov's early arguments, contemporary
behavioral psychologists argue that the unconditional nature of the
unconditioned stimulus-unconditional response stems from the orga-
nism's innate biological constitution (i.e., it is a reﬂex that was hard-
wired into the organism's nervous system throughout the organism's
species evolutionary history) (Power & Schulkin, 2008).
During the conditioning process, the neutral stimulus is repeatedly
brought into association with an unconditional stimulus and, as a
consequence, begins to elicit the same set of unconditioned responses as
the unconditioned stimulus, though with less intensity.

Likewise, Pavlov called the set of responses associated with
unconditioned stimuli unconditional responses because the responses
unconditionally resulted from the organism's exposure to the uncondi-
tional
stimulus. Building upon Pavlov's early arguments, contemporary
behavioral psychologists argue that the unconditional nature of the
unconditioned stimulus-unconditional response stems from the orga-
nism's innate biological constitution (i.e., it is a reﬂex that was hard-
wired into the organism's nervous system throughout the organism's
species evolutionary history) (Power & Schulkin, 2008).
During the conditioning process, the neutral stimulus is repeatedly
brought into association with an unconditional stimulus and, as a
consequence, begins to elicit the same set of unconditioned responses as
the unconditioned stimulus, though with less intensity. Given the
nature of the underlying associations and how they form, behavioral
psychologists sometimes refer to classical conditioning process as
learning through stimulus substitution. This is because, the previously
neutral stimulus can now besubstituted for the unconditioned stimulus
as the trigger for the unconditioned responses (Lefrançois, 2012:31). As
Pavlov initially surmised, and contemporary research has conﬁrmed,
conditional/conditioned stimuli gain the ability to elicit conditional/
conditioned responses as a neurological connection develops between
those brain regions that detect the stimulus and those brain regions that
coordinate the set of responses (Todes, 2014).
4.1.2. Declarative memory
Declarative forms of learning and memory are: (1) are forms of long-
K.R. Proctor and R.E. Niemeyer Journal of Criminal Justice xxx (xxxx) xxxx
4

term memory; (2) are consciously accessible to individuals; (3) can be
verbally communicated between individuals; and (4) contain the to-
tality of knowledge one possesses, including knowledge pertaining to
personal experiences and general knowledge (Squire & Dede, 2015).
There are three types of declarative memory, all of which are directly
relevant to social learning theory: episodic, semantic, and auto-
biographical memories.
4.1.2.1. Episodic memory. Episodic memory is declarative memory for
spatiotemporally speci ﬁc events individuals experience ﬁrst-
hand— including the details of the event, as well as the thoughts and
visceral sensations experienced while perceiving these details (Cohen,
Poldrack, & Eichenbaum, 1997; Diana & Wang, 2018; Eichenbaum,
2004; Naya, 2016;Teyler & Rudy, 2007). Like nondeclarative memory,
the mechanism for creating episodic memory can be speciﬁed at both a
psycho-behavioral level and a neurological level of explanation (Diana
& Wang, 2018 ). At the psycho-behavioral level, the mechanism
generating episodic memory is divided into three phases: encoding,
storage, and retrieval. Numerous factors are known to a ﬀect the
encoding, storage, and retrieval of episodic memory individually
(Diana & Wang, 2018), and creating precise theories of learning and
memory requires accounting for these diﬀerent phases and how each
may be aﬀected by these various factors.
Encoding is the initial process by which a perceived experience is
transformed into a lasting memory. Encoding consists of forming the
contextual associations between the properties that deﬁne a speciﬁc
event, boundaries between the event and other similar or related
events, and various retrieval cues that enable individuals to retrieve the
many remembered aspects of a single event. Encoding is particularly
sensitive to the amount of attention an individual gives to an aspect of
an event (Diana & Wang, 2018). During storage, recently encoded
memories are transformed over time into more durable and long-lasting
representations; it is also during this time that individual episodic
memories are organized and cross-referenced based on shared attri-
butes and other similarities. Retrieval is when a stored episodic memory
is actively recalled. Research indicates episodic memories are stored as
composites of the attributes that deﬁ ne an event, not as an un-
diﬀerentiated whole. Consequently, the retrieval of episodic memory
consists of reconstituting the remembered event from the individual
stored elements that comprise it (Diana & Wang, 2018). As such, re-
trieval of episodic memory can be aﬀected when spurious orﬁctitious
elements are incorrectly included in the reconstitution of the re-
membered event (Diana & Wang, 2018).
Further research is needed to specify the neurological mechanisms
that fully enable the encoding, storage, and retrieval; it is generally
acknowledged that the medial temporal lobe plays an essential role
(Diana & Wang, 2018; Squire & Dede, 2015). Extensive animal and
human research shows that the medial temporal lobe can be divided
into a number of structurally, and functionally distinct regions, in-
cluding the hippocampus, entorhinal, perirhinal, and parahippocampal
cortices
(Diana & Wang, 2018; Squire & Dede, 2015), which are hier-
archically organized in terms of informationﬂow between them. In one
theoretical model (Diana & Wang, 2018), the perirhinal cortex receives
visual information about what an object is, and the parahippocampal
cortex receives visual information about the object's physical location.
Both sets of information are then projected to the hippocampus, which
integrates the content of each to create the object-object and object-
context associations that deﬁne an episodic event (Diana & Wang,
2018).
4.1.2.2. Semantic memory . Semantic memory contains general
knowledge, which is devoid of the situational knowledge present in
episodic memory (Squire & Dede, 2015).

In one
theoretical model (Diana & Wang, 2018), the perirhinal cortex receives
visual information about what an object is, and the parahippocampal
cortex receives visual information about the object's physical location.
Both sets of information are then projected to the hippocampus, which
integrates the content of each to create the object-object and object-
context associations that deﬁne an episodic event (Diana & Wang,
2018).
4.1.2.2. Semantic memory . Semantic memory contains general
knowledge, which is devoid of the situational knowledge present in
episodic memory (Squire & Dede, 2015). This allows individuals to
arrive at generalizations of meaning through repeated exposure to
information within the environment, which produces abstract
knowledge such as schemas ( Rudy, 2014; Yee, Jones, & McRae,
2018). The schemas stored as semantic memory are organized into
taxonomies or thematic relationships, and a given schema can be
simultaneously organized into both types (Jackson, Hoﬀman, Pobric, &
Lambon Ralph, 2015). Taxonomies involve categorization based upon
shared attributes among schemas and intra-class memberships to
abstract categories (e.g., di ﬀerent types of handguns). Thematic
relationships relate to the spatial and temporal associations present
between schemas pertaining to two or more diﬀerent things, such as the
link between ‘soldiers’and ‘assault riﬂes,’ which are bound by their
spatiotemporal co-occurrence. Extensive research indicates that the
anterior temporal lobe and angular gyrus are critical brain regions
involved in creating and maintaining these abstraction representations
(Yee et al., 2018).
Researchers hypothesize there are at least three possible mechan-
isms producing semantic memories (Yee et al., 2018). In theﬁrst pro-
posed mechanism, semantic information is initially stored in the brain
as episodic memory. Over time, as the information is repeatedly ex-
perienced across multiple events, the memory becomes generalized as
the various properties unique to each event are abstracted away in
favor of the common elements. The second proposed mechanism argues
that semantic memory is created directly from experience by encoding
only the general features of an event and ignoring the various idio-
syncratic features. The third hypothesis proposes that semantic memory
is most eﬃciently derived from episodic memory, but that semantic
memory can also be derived directly from experience slowly and over
many, many repeated experiences.
4.1.2.3. Autobiographical memory. Autobiographical memory is a form
of self-relevant memory that contains properties of both episodic and
semantic memory (Renoult et al., 2016; Renoult, Davidson, Palombo,
Moscovitch, & Levine, 2012). In regard to episodic memory, it contains
information about one's self within a given historical experience and the
relevance of the experience to the individual. In regard to semantic
memory, autobiographical memory contains self-relevant information
that
is generalized in nature and lacks contextual details, with such
information partially serving as the basis of identities (seeNiemeyer,
2013).
Researchers have yet to fully elucidate the exact nature of auto-
biographical memory ( Gilboa, Rosenbaum, & Mendelsohn, 2018);
however, a growing body of empirical evidence suggests at least three
basic characteristics. First, although episodic and semantic auto-
biographical memory appear to be encoded using similar brain regions
as other forms of declarative memory, they nonetheless appear distinct
from more general forms of episodic and semantic memory (Brown,
Rissman, Chow, Uncapher, & Wagner, 2018;Chen, Gilmore, Nelson, &
McDermott, 2017; Ramanan, 2017). Second, autobiographical mem-
ories are not directly recalled in the same form that they are ultimately
experienced by those recalling them (Svoboda, McKinnon, & Levine,
2006). Instead, autobiographical memories appear to be actively con-
structed from more basic declarative memories (including episodic and
semantic memories) ( Inman, James, Vytal, & Hamann, 2018;
McCormick, Moscovitch, Valiante, Cohn, & McAndrews, 2018; Svoboda
et al., 2006).

Second, autobiographical mem-
ories are not directly recalled in the same form that they are ultimately
experienced by those recalling them (Svoboda, McKinnon, & Levine,
2006). Instead, autobiographical memories appear to be actively con-
structed from more basic declarative memories (including episodic and
semantic memories) ( Inman, James, Vytal, & Hamann, 2018;
McCormick, Moscovitch, Valiante, Cohn, & McAndrews, 2018; Svoboda
et al., 2006). Third, the construction of an autobiographical memory
appears to rely on other cognitive processes such as theory of mind,
working memory, and the ability to construct a narrative (Andrews-
Hanna, Saxe, & Yarkoni, 2014 ; Goddard, Dritschel, Robinson, &
Howlin, 2014).
The regions of the brain involved in the mechanism of auto-
biographical memory vary depending upon how an autobiographical
memory is being recalled, what is being recalled, and for what reason
(Sheldon et al., 2018). For example, in their literature review,Sheldon
et al. (2018) identify the medial temporal lobe, hippocampus, ven-
trolateral and medial prefrontal cortices, lateral temporal lobes, pos-
teromedial cortical regions, and posterior inferior parietal lobes as the
distributed network of brain regions that are consistently shown to
underlie autobiographical memory. At the same time, though, the
K.R. Proctor and R.E. Niemeyer Journal of Criminal Justice xxx (xxxx) xxxx
5

medial prefrontal cortex has consistently been shown to be critical to
the self-referential aspects of autobiographical memory, while the
precuneus and lateral temporal cortex are crucial to visual imagery
processing and conceptual processing, respectively ( Sheldon et al.,
2018). As in the case of episodic memory, the hippocampus plays an
important role in integrating the various aspects of an autobiographical
memory into a cohesive whole; however, research indicates that how
strongly the hippocampus engages with the frontal cortices depends on
whether one is retrieving a vivid or non-vivid memory (Sheldon et al.,
2018).
5. Theoretical retroﬁtting of social learning theory
The current statement of social learning theory, with its reliance on
behaviorism as an underlying paradigm, lacks the conceptual frame-
work required to respond adequately to its critics. We contend ques-
tions surrounding the theory's empirical validity and conceptual clarity
are best addressed byﬁrst retroﬁtting the theory with modern under-
standings of learning and memory present within cognitive psychology
and neuroscience, as this greatly enhances conceptual clarity within the
theory and allows for more meaningful future tests of it. The retroﬁt
model of social learning theory is presented inFig. 2. In the sections
that follow, we describe each element of the proposed revision, as well
as identify how the retroﬁt models address the aforementioned criti-
cisms of the theory.
5.1. Diﬀerential associations
Within the retroﬁt social learning model, the concept of diﬀerential
associations is retained, which includes associations individuals have
with others, as well as interactions one has with various forms of media
(Akers, 2009). Like the current statement of social learning theory
(Akers, 2009), one's diﬀerential associations are also seen within the
retroﬁt model as being the primary context within which the various
mechanisms of learning occur.
5.2. Learning mechanisms and memories
The retroﬁt model of social learning posits that one's diﬀerential
associations lead to criminal behavior through multiple distinct, but
possibly co-occurring forms of learning which produce distinct forms of
memory. These include actions and habits, conditioned behaviors, se-
mantic memories, episodic memories, and autobiographical memories.
The retroﬁt model abandons the concept of deﬁnitions as it is currently
deﬁned because it conﬂates diﬀerent forms of memory, the majority of
which are not produced through operant conditioning or vicarious re-
inforcement.
5.2.1. Actions and habits
Social learning theory (Akers, 2009) contends individuals acquire
the skills necessary to engage in crime through operant conditioning or
vicarious reinforcement. The theory's emphasis on skills is directly de-
rived from its origins within diﬀerential association theory, where
Sutherland (1947, [1942] 1956) contended individuals learned the
techniques (i.e., skills) required to engage in criminal behavior, which
could be either simple or complex in nature. A key component of Su-
therland's conception of skills was that the skills involved in criminal
behavior were often also skills involved in non-criminal behavior
(Sutherland, 1942 1956). Within the retroﬁt model, the concept of skills
is respeciﬁed as a form of nondeclarative memory that includes actions
and habits. The ability to engage in criminalactions is learned through
one's criminogenic diﬀerential associations through two distinct, but
intertwined, forms of learning: operant and vicarious operant con-
ditioning. Through operant conditioning, people learn to engage in
criminal actions as a result of being rewarded or punished for engaging
in a speciﬁc action in response to a stimulus. Criminalhabits are ac-
quired through the repeated engagement in and rewarding of criminal
actions.
Our review of contemporary deﬁnitions of learning and memory
reveals social learning theory (Akers, 2009) contains several problems
in its conception of operating conditioning. First, social learning theory
does not suﬃciently diﬀerentiate between actions and habits, recognize
distinctions in their productive mechanisms, or diﬀerentiate between
Fig. 2.Retroﬁt social learning theory model.
K.R. Proctor and R.E. Niemeyer Journal of Criminal Justice xxx (xxxx) xxxx
6

the properties of behaviors resulting from them. Second, social learning
theory's conception of imitation as a distinct form of learning is in-
correct regarding actions. As noted byBandura (1971), “[the] operant
conditioning analysis of modeling phenomena [e.g., imitation]… relies
entirely upon the standard three-component paradigm Sd ➔ R ➔ Sr ,
where Sd denotes the modeled stimulus, R represents an overt matching
response, and Sr designates the reinforcing stimulus” (xix). Thus, vi-
carious reinforcement is a special case of operant conditioning, one
more appropriately labeled vicarious operant conditioning.
Vicarious operant conditioning occurs through a general process of
sensorimotor-based intersubjective resonance, whereby observed ac-
tions performed by another trigger an individual to unconsciously recall
one's motor plan related to the observed act (Herbert, Lafargue, Moritz-
Gasser, Bonnetblanc, & Duﬀau, 2015). The motor plan recalled includes
the motions, actions, and immediate goals involved in the observed
behavior, with motions relating to speciﬁc body movements, actions
involving integrations of motions in reference to a target object, and
immediate goals pertaining to the consequences of the action
(Schaafsma, Pfaﬀ, Spunt, & Adolphs, 2015;Spunt, Falk, & Lieberman,
2010; Van Overwalle & Baetens, 2009). Vicarious operant conditioning
occurs when an individual observes the actions of another in relation to
an object, recalls motor plans related to the actions of the observed
individual through sensorimotor-based resonance, and observes the
individual achieve a speciﬁc immediate goal as a consequence of the
person's actions (Monfardini et al., 2013). In terms of the three-part
sequence, Bandura (1971) describes— Sd ➔ R ➔ Sr— the term Sd re-
presents the observed modeled action, R represents the process of
sensorimotor-based intersubjective resonance, and Sr represents the
observed reinforcing stimulus. Through this mechanism, the observer
comes to associate speciﬁc motor plans with speciﬁc immediate goals
by observing the actions of another being reinforced.
The magnitude of vicarious operant learning varies across in-
dividuals based on at least two conditions ( Kibler & Shea, 2005;
Sumanapala & Cross, 2017). First, the magnitude is greater when ob-
servers already possess the various motor plans that either directly or
closely corresponded to one or more aspects of the actions engaged in
by the observed individual (Eaves, Emerson, Binks, Scott, & Kenny,
2018; Kirsch & Cross, 2015; Sumanapala, Fish, Jones, & Cross, 2017).
Second, vicarious learning is more eﬀective when individuals explicitly
practice the observed action so that the behavioral sequence can be
consolidated into a single motor plan through operant conditioning
(Eaves et al., 2018; Ossmy & Mukamel, 2018;Spampinato & Celnik,
2018; Vogt & Thomaschke, 2007).
Operant conditioning can also occur through observational learning
(Maslovat, Hayes, Horn, & Hodges, 2010). In observational learning, a
model formallydemonstrates the action to an observing individual, asks
the observing individual to repeat the demonstrated action, and pro-
vides positive and negative feedback to the observing individual as he
or she practices what was observed. Here, the term Sd represents the
model formally demonstrating the action, R represents the individual
formally practicing the action while being observed by the model, and
Sr represents the reinforcing stimulus provided by the model in re-
sponse to the individual's performance of the action.
In a study examining tutelage within diﬀerential association theory,
McCarthy (1996) found a signi ﬁcant association between tutelage
(having someone oﬀer to help engage in crime, actually help engage in
crime, or tell the respondent how to make money oﬀ crime) and drug
dealing and theft. While the study lacks suﬃcient precision to de-
termine whether vicarious reinforcement or observational learning
were associated with crime as forms of tutelage, nonetheless, the evi-
dence suggests that either form of learning could play a signiﬁcant role
in the learning of criminal behavior.

model formally demonstrating the action, R represents the individual

McCarthy (1996) found a signi ﬁcant association between tutelage
(having someone oﬀer to help engage in crime, actually help engage in
crime, or tell the respondent how to make money oﬀ crime) and drug
dealing and theft. While the study lacks suﬃcient precision to de-

were associated with crime as forms of tutelage, nonetheless, the evi-
dence suggests that either form of learning could play a signiﬁcant role
in the learning of criminal behavior.
The retroﬁt statement of social learning theory adds much-needed
precision to the theory directly pertaining to operant conditioning, vi-
carious reinforcement, and eﬀorts to operationalize and empirically
validate the theory. The retroﬁt model speciﬁes that the skills necessary
to commit a crime can be learned through three distinct but related
mechanisms: operant conditioning, vicarious operant conditioning, and
observational learning. Unlike operant conditioning, which entails in-
strumental learning through trial and error, vicarious operant con-
ditioning and observational learning represent guided means for
learning a skill. Whereas vicarious operant conditioning is passive, in-
volving no interaction with another demonstrating the use of a skill to
achieve a desired goal, observational learning involves direct interac-
tion and tutelage.
The retroﬁt statement of social theory also allows criminologists to
distinguish empirically between instruction-based operant learning and
purely operant learning, something that critics (Brauer & Tittle, 2012)
argue is currently impossible within the classic social learning theory
framework. As noted earlier when introducing the concept of actions,
the internal models generated by the action system and stored in
working memory create both a set of expectations about how the im-
mediate situation should change if the proper response is performed,
and a corresponding set of behaviors for achieving the outcome. As also
was noted, internal models are built-up from various forms of memory
that were learned during previous experiences in similar situations.
According to recent research, though, the semantic knowledge stored in
an individual's memory that is triggered by the verbal instructions can
both populate the individual's internal model and provide the same
function as memories learned from previous direct experience (Doll
et al., 2015; Redish, 2016). Despite their functional equivalence within
internal models, verbal instructions can nonetheless be empirically
distinguished through a variety of research technologies (see, e.g.,
Lauren Y. Atlas, 2019;L .Y . Atlas, Doll, Li, Daw, & Phelps, 2016).
Consequently, the retroﬁt statement of social learning theory gives
criminologists the ability to both conceptually and empirically assess if,
when, and how verbal instructions facilitate deviant behavior under
diﬀerent situational contexts.
5.2.2. Conditioned behaviors
While social learning theory (Akers, 2009) acknowledges the ex-
istence of classical conditioning, the theory contends it is not important
for explaining criminal behavior. Contrary to this claim, however,
classical conditioning can be a powerful source of learning criminal
motivations; one example of this is vicarious classical conditioning.
Vicarious classical conditioning involves classical conditioning and
emotional contagion, a process mediated by the mirror neuron system
that allows individuals to automatically simulate the emotions of others
(Harada, Hayashi, Sadato, & Iidaka, 2016; Nummenmaa, Hirvonen,
Parkkola, & Hietanen, 2008). The automatic simulation of the emotions
of others occurs through the previously discussed mechanism of sen-
sorimotor-based intersubjective resonance, which produces a low-level
understanding of the emotional states of others (Keysers & Gazzola,
2014).
Emotional contagion is possible, in part, because the physical mo-
tions involved in expressing emotions, such as smiling, involve motor
plans. The mechanism producing emotional contagion involves: (1) an
observer; (2) a person being observed; and (3) a physical display of
emotion, typically on one's face, by the person being observed.

The automatic simulation of the emotions
of others occurs through the previously discussed mechanism of sen-
sorimotor-based intersubjective resonance, which produces a low-level
understanding of the emotional states of others (Keysers & Gazzola,
2014).
Emotional contagion is possible, in part, because the physical mo-
tions involved in expressing emotions, such as smiling, involve motor
plans. The mechanism producing emotional contagion involves: (1) an
observer; (2) a person being observed; and (3) a physical display of
emotion, typically on one's face, by the person being observed. Once the
observed person facially displays an emotional response, the observer
subconsciously accesses their motor plan for the emotional display,
which activates parts of the brain that generate the emotions associated
with the observed facial expression (Niedenthal, Mermillod, Maringer,
& Hess, 2010;A .Wood, Rychlowska, Korb, & Niedenthal, 2016). The
observer might not experience a conscious emotional change
(Niedenthal et al., 2010; Wood et al., 2016); nonetheless, the observer
subconsciously simulates and experiences the emotional state of the
person being observed.
Consequently, a person can bevicariously classically conditioned to
experience speciﬁc emotions in response to a speciﬁc stimulus by ob-
serving another having an emotional response to the same stimulus
(Askew & Field, 2008). This possibility creates a new source for

7

learning motivations within social learning theory that is not tied to
operant conditioning as one can be conditioned to experience positive
or negative emotional states and be unaware of why they are experi-
encing them because this form of memory is not consciously accessible
to actors (Robinson, Robinson, & Berridge, 2013). One powerful ex-
ample of this form of learning relates to racism. Based upon the me-
chanisms involved in vicarious classical conditioning, it is possible for a
child to associate speciﬁc racial groups with negative emotions by
merely observing the negative facial expressions of others, such as
primary groups members (Conger, Dygdon, & Rollock, 2012). Thus,
insofar as emotions serve as a basis of motivation, the emotional states
resulting from vicarious classical conditioning can serve asunconscious
motivations for crime (e.g., the use of racial epitaphs or commission of
hate crimes) within the retroﬁtted social learning theory (see, e.g.,
Talaska, Fiske, & Chaiken, 2008).
Psychological research has also identiﬁed the types of people that
are most likely to inﬂuence a person when vicarious operant con-
ditioning is occurring (for a review, seeDebiec & Olsson, 2017). Re-
search shows that an individual's perceived degree of relatedness and
similarity to, as well as familiarity with, an observed other signiﬁcantly
inﬂuences the degree to which vicariously classical conditioning occurs.
Likewise, research has shown that perceived social dominance and level
of attributed skill aﬀect the degree to which vicarious classical con-
ditioning occurs. Further, the degree to which individuals empathize
with observed others also aﬀects vicarious classical conditioning.
Taken together, the inclusion of vicarious classical conditioning
within the retroﬁt model of social learning theory provides numerous
new opportunities to explore how emotions and emotional contagion
might inﬂuence criminal motivation. Additionally, since emotions can
inﬂuence operant conditioning insofar as they relate to the goals one is
pursuing (e.g., the alleviation of fear or releasing frustration), the
phenomenon of vicarious classical conditioning might also help to ex-
plain skill formation in regard to speciﬁc crimes.
5.2.3. Semantic memory
Social learning theory (Akers, 2009) states that individuals learn
deﬁnitions through operant conditioning. Depending on the kind of
deﬁnition, however, this is not physiologically possible. Attitudes and
neutralizations are forms of semantic knowledge that cannot be learned
through operant conditioning. Instead, semantic memory inﬂuences the
mechanism of operant conditioning insofar as a person's attitudes or
neutralizations aﬀect the action plan one generates (Borghesani et al.,
2016; Kalénine & Buxbaum, 2016; Quandt, Lee, & Chatterjee, 2017).
Further, semantic memory also inﬂuences the mechanism of vicarious
operant conditioning insofar as an individual's attitudes or neutraliza-
tions aﬀect one's symbolic deﬁ nitions or interpretations of others
(Golkar, Castro, & Olsson, 2015; Golkar & Olsson, 2017 ) and their ob-
served actions (Gerson, Meyer, Hunnius, & Bekkering, 2017; Hudson,
Nicholson, Ellis, & Bach, 2016; Joiner, Piva, Turrin, & Chang, 2017;
Yang, Rosenblau, Keifer, & Pelphrey, 2015).
Likewise, social learning theory's concept of motives is also mis-
speciﬁed. Insofar as motives are consciously accessible to actors, mo-
tives cannot be learned through operant conditioning and instead are
best conceptualized under traditional sociological conceptions of values
(i.e., social goals). Insofar as motives relate to drives or basic biological
imperatives, these, too, are not learned through operant condition as
they are not a form of learned behavior. Instead, their salience in a
given situation inﬂuences the formation of an action plan within op-
erant conditioning but are not themselves a product of operant con-
ditioning.

Likewise, social learning theory's concept of motives is also mis-
speciﬁed. Insofar as motives are consciously accessible to actors, mo-
tives cannot be learned through operant conditioning and instead are
best conceptualized under traditional sociological conceptions of values
(i.e., social goals). Insofar as motives relate to drives or basic biological
imperatives, these, too, are not learned through operant condition as
they are not a form of learned behavior. Instead, their salience in a
given situation inﬂuences the formation of an action plan within op-
erant conditioning but are not themselves a product of operant con-
ditioning.
In regard to criticisms that social learning theory artiﬁcial conﬂates
reinforcements and anticipated reinforcements, the phenomenon of
semantic memory can be used to partially resolve this criticism in the
retroﬁt model. Since the product of operant conditioning, a motor plan,
is not consciously accessible knowledge, it is not physiologically pos-
sible for operant conditioning to produce consciously accessible
knowledge of causes and eﬀects. Insofar as an individual possess such
knowledge, and it is consciously accessible and abstract, then such
knowledge must be stored within semantic memory as a schema— or,
more speciﬁcally, a script (see, e.g.,Schank & Abelson, 1977)— which
speciﬁes how a typical event should unfold. Should an individual pos-
sess such a script, it was either learned through symbolic communica-
tion or the generalization of episodic memories into an abstract script,
not through operant conditioning.
5.2.4. Episodic memory
Social learning theory ( Akers, 2009) does not include episodic
memory in its explanation of crime, although this form of memory can
be partially related to social learning theory's concept of anticipated
reinforcements, as was the case with semantic memory in the previous
section. Social learning theory contends an outcome of operant con-
ditioning is that a person learns which behaviors are reinforced by a
speciﬁc stimulus. Consequently, in future situations, a person chooses
to engage in the behavior that one anticipates will be reinforced based
upon the previously discussed matching function. Since operant con-
ditioning is not physiologically capable of generating consciously ac-
cessible memories, however, memories of a speciﬁc event are learned in
parallel to operant conditioning through encoding, storage, and re-
trieval and are stored as episodic memories. Thus, it is possible for
anticipated reinforcements to be episodic memories that can be con-
sciously accessed and used when formulating action plans as part of
operant conditioning.
5.2.5. Autobiographical memory
Autobiographical memory, like other forms of declarative memory,
is not explicitly present within social learning theory. Certain concepts
within social learning, however, suggest the presence of auto-
biographical memory in its explanation of crime. With neutralization
theory, for example,Sykes and Matza (1957)note that one function of
neutralizations is to allow delinquents to preserve their self-images as
conformists even though they are, in fact, deviants. The idea that a
delinquent has a self-image necessitates the presence of a form of
memory where such a self-image is stored. Likewise, within social
learning theory, a person forms a deﬁnition of self that plays a role in
self-regulation. According toAkers (2009), self-regulation occurs when
an individual punishes him- or herself or anticipates the reinforcements
others might apply regarding a speciﬁc act. By combining this concept
with that of anticipated reinforcement, it is possible for an individual to
anticipate a self-imposed reinforcement relating to a speciﬁc act. Con-
sequently, this obscure component of social learning theory implies that
anticipated self-reinforcement could be of etiological signiﬁcance.
In the retroﬁt model of social learning theory, this has several im-
plications. First, as operant conditioning relates solely to skills, social
learning theory's mechanism of self-regulation is physiologically not
possible in at least two ways. One way is that meanings stored in au-
tobiographical memory are derived from episodic and semantic mem-
ories that are self-relevant.

According toAkers (2009), self-regulation occurs when
an individual punishes him- or herself or anticipates the reinforcements
others might apply regarding a speciﬁc act. By combining this concept
with that of anticipated reinforcement, it is possible for an individual to
anticipate a self-imposed reinforcement relating to a speciﬁc act. Con-
sequently, this obscure component of social learning theory implies that
anticipated self-reinforcement could be of etiological signiﬁcance.
In the retroﬁt model of social learning theory, this has several im-
plications. First, as operant conditioning relates solely to skills, social
learning theory's mechanism of self-regulation is physiologically not
possible in at least two ways. One way is that meanings stored in au-
tobiographical memory are derived from episodic and semantic mem-
ories that are self-relevant. If a person had felt bad in the past after
engaging in an act, the emotion experienced would be attached to the
autobiographical episodic memory and could function as an auto-
biographical-episodic form of reinforcement. A second way is that the
autobiographical memory might contain abstract knowledge of one's
self that holds the person is not the kind of person who engages in
criminal behavior. Thus, the person would not refrain out of fear of
punishment, but instead out of the abstract sense the behavior is in-
consistent with‘who they are’and the individual would not feel‘right’
about it. In neither case is operant conditioning at play.
Second, the previous examples suggest that self-relevant meanings
can serve as a basis for motivation. Insofar as a person fears what he or
she will feel after engaging in a crime or possesses a sense of self that
must be maintained, either can serve as a source of behavior motiva-
tion. Although some have suggested this possibility (e.g.,Asencio &
Burke, 2011), it remains largely outside of the traditional social

learning theory framework but not outside of the retroﬁt model.
5.2.6. The matching function
Based on the retroﬁt model, the matching function no longer pro-
vides an adequate explanation as to why individuals engage in crime
within a particular situation. Since the matching function is a vestigial
element of the previous version of social learning theory, which is en-
cumbered by its behaviorist origins, the matching function serves as a
placeholder in the retroﬁt model until a suitable replacement can be
identiﬁed. While this is beyond the scope of this paper, a suitable re-
placement for the matching will likely depend on mechanisms related
to theory of mind that allow individuals to engage in mental simula-
tions to arrive at courses of action (see Proctor & Niemeyer, 2019:
Chapter 14).
6. Methodological implications
The retroﬁt model of social learning theory has several methodo-
logical implications depending on the form of memory being empiri-
cally examined. As nondeclarative forms of memory are not consciously
accessible to individuals, traditional survey methods employed by
criminologists cannot directly observe the content stored within non-
declarative memory. Declarative memory, however, is highly amenable
to being investigated through survey methods. In the following sec-
tions, we further elaborate on how each form of memory can be em-
pirically examined. As an exhaustive review of the applicable cognitive
psychological and neuroscientiﬁc methods is beyond the scope of this
paper due to space constraints, we limit our discussion of methods from
theseﬁelds to a handful of methods that directly pertain to the retroﬁt
model of social learning theory.
6.1. Actions and habits
Within the retroﬁt model of social learning theory, actions can be
learned through several distinct mechanistic pathways: (1) operant
conditioning; (2) vicarious operant conditioning; and (3) observational
learning. As previously discussed, verbal instructions can inﬂuence
operant learning by populating the internal model present within an
action plan with semantic knowledge regarding expected outcomes for
a given act and the speciﬁc actions associated with producing the de-
sired outcome. These properties of actions, as well as their non-
declarative nature, have several empirical and methodological im-
plications for the retroﬁt model.
First, the three mechanisms involved in learning skills— operant
conditioning, vicarious operant conditioning, and observational lear-
ning— should progressively accelerate the learning process, with op-
erant conditioning alone being the slowest means of acquiring a new
skill, vicarious reinforcement producing more rapid learning because of
the presence of a model, and observational learning being the fastest
means of acquiring new skills because it involves tutoring by the be-
havioral model (Ruge et al., 2018).
Second, insofar as interview or survey methods involving re-
spondent self-reporting are being employed to measure these three
forms of learning, it is important to note that all such methods only
indirectly measure operant conditioning mechanisms and the skills they
produce. This is because the product of operant conditioning is a skill
that is stored in memory as a motor plan that is not consciously ac-
cessible to an actor. Since, however, episodic and autobiographical
memories can form in parallel with operant conditioning (Dunsmoor &
Kroes, 2019; Raber et al., 2019), survey methods are capable of mea-
suring episodic or autobiographical memories that are formed si-
multaneously when one is learning through operant conditioning. Thus,
it is possible to ask respondents how they learned a crime-speciﬁc skill
even if this only indirectly measures the precise operant conditioning
mechanism through which the skill was learned.
Survey instruments can, therefore, be designed toindirectly measure
the form of operant conditioning that was operating when a person
learned a criminal skill. Should a skill be learned through operant
conditioning, survey questions should identify whether a person was
exposed
to a behavioral model when learning the skill to diﬀerentiate
between operant and vicarious operant conditioning mechanisms.
Likewise, if the respondent has been exposed to a model, questions
should measure whether the behavioral modeling occurred in a passive
or active manner.Figs.

Question 7 attempts to measure whether a respondent has ever received
instructions for how to hotwire a car from another in the absence of
behavioral modeling or observational learning. Thus, this question is
designed to measure whether one has been exposed to hotwiring
scripts, and Question 8 attempts to measure the magnitude of this ex-
posure for respondents for whom it is applicable.
Lastly, Fig. 5 contains an example of a survey question that is in-
tended to measure operant conditioning solely. Within the question, a
respondent is asked about how frequently a responded hotwired a car
alone when he or she wasﬁrst learning how to hotwire cars.
While it is possible to indirectly measure forms of operant con-
ditioning using a survey instrument, as illustrated inFigs. 4–5, doing
gives rise to at least two problems. For one, episodic memories are
prone to errors in information retrieval during the recall process, which
can aﬀect the accuracy of survey responses (Carpenter & Schacter,
2017, 2018a, 2018b; Principe, Guiliano, & Root, 2008). Another sig-
niﬁcant problem is that a respondent might, in fact, be answering ret-
rospective questions using semantic memory, which is devoid of si-
tuational knowledge in cases where numerous similar episodic
memories have been abstracted to form semantic memories that are
relevant to a given survey question. In such cases, a respondent is no
longer recalling speciﬁc past events but is instead making inferences
about the past based upon abstract knowledge stored in semantic
memory. Consequently, such cases are prone to inference errors (De
Neys, Schaeken, & D'Ydewalle, 2003 ; Dickstein, 1980; Oaksford &
Chater, 2010). Thus, eﬀorts to indirectly measure operant conditioning
mechanisms utilizing episodic memory are subject to forms of mea-
surement error that are unique to the form of declarative memory being
used by a respondent when answering survey questions.
Third, criminologists could also employ experimental methods to
determine how one's experiences with diﬀerent forms of operant con-
ditioning aﬀect how long it takes for an individual to acquire a given
criminal skill, as well as one's proﬁciency with it. For example, the
diﬀerent forms of operant conditioning measured in the survey instru-
ment presented inFigs. 3–5 could serve as the basis for diﬀerent groups
to which a person could be randomly assigned within an experiment in
regard to the same task (e.g., hotwiring a car). Traditional ANOVA or
ANCOVA analysis could be conducted to determining if speciﬁc forms
of learning produce the faster acquisition of a skill or higher levels of
proﬁciency.
Fourth, criminologists could directly measure if, how, and when
verbal instructions aﬀect operant learning of criminal and deviant be-
havior by either adopting the same research methodologies employed
by cognitive neuroscientists and psychologists when investigating si-
milar research questions or by integrating the results of these studies as
an indirect crucial test. For example, within theﬁelds of psychology
and cognitive neuroscience, human learning that occurs vis-à-vis in-
structions, instead of by direct experience, is called either instruction-
based learning (IBL) or rapid instructed task learning (RITL) (Ruge,
Schäfer, Zwosta, Mohr, & Wolfensteller, 2019). Although contemporary
empirical research on IBL/RITL is still emerging (Liefooghe, Braem, &
Meiran,
2018), there is already a general consensus within the litera-
ture that several brain regions underlying working memory play a
critical role in the process (Cole, Laurent, & Stocco, 2013; Liefooghe
et al., 2018; Ruge et al., 2019).

For example, within theﬁelds of psychology
and cognitive neuroscience, human learning that occurs vis-à-vis in-
structions, instead of by direct experience, is called either instruction-
based learning (IBL) or rapid instructed task learning (RITL) (Ruge,
Schäfer, Zwosta, Mohr, & Wolfensteller, 2019). Although contemporary
empirical research on IBL/RITL is still emerging (Liefooghe, Braem, &
Meiran,
2018), there is already a general consensus within the litera-
ture that several brain regions underlying working memory play a
critical role in the process (Cole, Laurent, & Stocco, 2013; Liefooghe
et al., 2018; Ruge et al., 2019). Speciﬁcally, the empirical evidence
suggests that a subset of brain regions within the working memory
system are responsible for maintaining the instructed stimulus-response
associations in mind (e.g., press the return key, the response, when the
word ‘coﬀee’is displayed), while other brain regions are responsible for
activating already-learned responses and organizing them into the se-
quence indicated by the instructions (Cole, Bagic, Kass, & Schneider,
2010; Meiran, Liefooghe, & De Houwer, 2017;Pereg & Meiran, 2019).
Consequently, given the neurological division of labor, it is possible for
criminologists to use fMRI (functional magnetic resonance imaging)
and other neuroimaging technologies to not only map how instructions
to commit criminal behavior activate and organize previously learned
skills and declarative knowledge as required by the criminal task, but
also how the neurological mechanism diﬀers from direct learning (see,
e.g., Koban, Jepma, López-Solà, & Wager, 2019).
Lastly, based upon these implications, criminologists could arrive at
a variety of indirect and direct measures of learning mechanisms for
empirical tests of the retroﬁt model that allow for the triangulation of
results. In doing so, they could better address claims that social learning
theory lacks empirical support for its claims and that concepts are not
suﬃciently diﬀerentiated from those in rival theories.
6.2. Conditioned behaviors
The inclusion of the classical conditioning within the retroﬁt model
of social learning theory also introduces new research methodologies
and technologies for assessing the causes of criminal motivations. For
example, contemporary behavioral psychologists routinely use a variety
of technologies to both individually detect and triangulate the eﬀects of
classical conditioning on the implicit racial biases referenced in our
discussion of vicarious classical conditioning (see, e.g.,Amodio, 2014;
Conger et al., 2012;Golkar, Björnstjerna, & Olsson, 2015;O'Donnell,
Neumann, Duﬀy, & Paolini, 2019).

One way to operationalize conditioned implicit racial biases is to
measure changes in individuals' startle response after exposure to per-
sons of color (Vanman, Ryan, Pedersen, & Ito, 2013). At its fullest ex-
pression, the startle response is “a whole-body ﬂexor reaction to
sudden, intense, stimulation whose function is defensive in nature,
designed to protect the organism from assault by closing the eyes,
ducking the head, and pulling in the limbs” (Bradley & Sabatinelli,
2003:65)— for example, imagine how an individual would react if a
loud gunshot unexpectedly went oﬀ right next to them. However, even
subtler stimuli, such as when individuals are exposed to persons of
color, can still generate an observable behavioral response, such as the
eyeblink reﬂex (Lang, Bradley, & Cuthbert, 1990)— which is an in-
voluntary blinking of the eyelids due to the contraction of the orbicu-
laris oculi muscle that surrounds the eye (Blumenthal et al., 2005;
Bradley & Sabatinelli, 2003; Sterling, 2013). The magnitude of the
eyeblink reﬂex is easily measured by placing two electromyographic
(EMG) recording electrodes on the surface of the skin above orbicularis
oculi muscle to record the level of electrical activity occurring within
the muscle (Bradley & Sabatinelli, 2003). This and other measures of
eyeblink response have been correlated with the presence or degree of
racial bias, such that the greater the magnitude and amplitude of the
recorded electrical signal, the stronger the eyeblink reﬂex; and the
stronger the eyeblink reﬂex, the larger the detected implicit racial bias
using other established indicators (March & Graham, 2014).
Another way to operationalize implicit racial biases is to use eye-
tracking software to measure changes in individuals' pupil dilation in
response to being exposed to racial other (see, e.g., Wu, Laeng, &
Magnussen, 2012). Like the aperture of a camera, pupils alter their size
to aﬀect the amount of light entering the eye to alter“the amount of
visual information that the brain receives, thus increasing visual sen-
sitivity; therefore, a dilated pupil, compared to a constricted pupil, al-
lows you to better detect faint stimuli” (Mathôt, 2018:9). Although
pupil size is automatically controlled by the pupillary light reﬂex in
response to changes in light intensity, pupils will also automatically
dilate when individuals experience an arousing stimulus, thought, or
emotion as a part of the‘ﬂight-or-ﬁght’response (Mathôt, 2018). For
this reason, a change in pupil dilation when viewing persons of color is
believed to be an indirect measure of arousal-level due to threat-based
stereotypes (Chekroud, Everett, Bridge, & Hewstone, 2014; Fleming,
Bandy, & Kimble, 2010) or other biases (Goldinger, He, & Papesh,
2009).
Still
another way to measure the eﬀects of classical conditioning on
implicit racial bias is to use neuroimaging technology to detect changes
in neural activity in the parts of the brain that initiate and coordinate
the various defensive responses associated with the startle re ﬂex
(Lonsdorf et al., 2017; Molapour, Golkar, Navarrete, Haaker, & Olsson,
2015). Furthermore, it is worth noting here that emerging research
demonstrates that it is possible to use fMRI to distinguish between vi-
carious and direct classical conditioning of implicit racial bias based on
slight diﬀerences in the brain regions involved in the generative me-
chanism underlying the experience ( Lindström, Haaker, & Olsson,
2018).
6.3. Episodic, semantic, and autobiographical memory
Along with their theoretical implications, integrating semantic,
episodic, and autobiographical memory into the retro ﬁtted social
learning theory has clear implications for how the theory is tested.

Furthermore, it is worth noting here that emerging research
demonstrates that it is possible to use fMRI to distinguish between vi-
carious and direct classical conditioning of implicit racial bias based on
slight diﬀerences in the brain regions involved in the generative me-
chanism underlying the experience ( Lindström, Haaker, & Olsson,
2018).
6.3. Episodic, semantic, and autobiographical memory
Along with their theoretical implications, integrating semantic,
episodic, and autobiographical memory into the retro ﬁtted social
learning theory has clear implications for how the theory is tested. First,
the fact that all three forms of declarative memory can be deliberately
recalled means criminologists can measure how semantic, episodic, and
autobiographical learning and knowledge inﬂuence criminal motiva-
tions through traditional interviews and surveys (see, e.g., Levine,
Svoboda, Hay, Winocur, & Moscovitch, 2002). Second, criminologists
can use neural imaging technologies, such as fMRI and EEG (electro-
encephalogram), to observe neural activity in the regions of the brain
that generate and recall all three forms of declarative memory when
engaging in criminal or deviant behavior, or diﬀer between noncriminal
and criminal motivations, behaviors, and contexts (see, e.g.,
Moscovitch, Nadel, Winocur, Gilboa, & Rosenbaum, 2006).
Key diﬀerences in how episodic, semantic, and autobiographical
memory are each constituted, stored, and recalled in the brain ne-
cessitates corresponding adjustments in how each form of memory is
measured. In short, because episodic memory is comprised of personal
experiences from a ﬁrst-person perspective, survey and interview
questions should be speciﬁcally worded to take these aspects of episodic
memory into account. Likewise, because semantic memory is devoid of
situational knowledge and a ﬁrst-person perspective, survey and in-
terview questions targeting semantic memory should not include these
features. Further, given that autobiographical memory characterizes
both episodic and general knowledge about oneself and one's experi-
ences, survey and interview questions should be explicitly constructed
to probe these diﬀerent forms of content.
Altering how a question or verbal task is stated in order to capture
diﬀerent forms of learning and memory is a well-established procedure
in psychology and cognitive neuroscience (see, e.g.,Palombo, Williams,
Abdi, & Levine, 2013), and the practice can be easily adopted by
criminologists. For example, questions designed to measure episodic,
semantic, and autobiographical memories that might be related to
criminal behavior are presented inFig. 6. Within theﬁgure, Questions

time the respondent did something he or she believed to be wrong, and
the respondent's parents knew about the act. These questions are de-
signed to take the respondent back to the time when the act was
committed and report how his or her parents emotionally reacted to the
