immoral behavior. Question 4 is designed to measure the respondent's
general stereotype or schema of how his or her parents typically emo-
tionally respond when the respondent engages in immoral activities.
Thus, Question 4, being devoid of speciﬁc situational information, is a
measure of semantic memory.
Lastly, Questions 5 and 6 are designed to measure one's auto-
biographical memories in relation to his or her immoral behavior.
Question 5 serves a measure of an autobiographical episodic memory
because it asks how he or she felt within a speciﬁc situation, while
Question 6 serves as a measure of an autobiographical semantic
memory because it asks how the respondent generally feels after com-
mitting an immoral act.
Integrating semantic, episodic, and autobiographical memory into
the retroﬁtted social learning theory further enables criminologists to
take into account the role false memories and other memory errors play
in the etiology of crime or in interview or survey research methodol-
ogies. Declarative memory is unique to the degree that individual
memories can be deliberately recalled, consciously decomposed, and
ﬂexibly recombined to infer novel situations or outcomes (Carpenter &
Schacter, 2018a; Schwabe, Nader, & Pruessner, 2014). However, ac-
cording to extensive research in both psychology and cognitive neu-
roscience, the same physical properties of the brain that give declara-
tive memory these characteristics also make them susceptible to
distortion. This is because the various associations constituting the
original memory are temporarily“loosened” during recall so that they
may be decomposed or recombined, and thus are temporarily vulner-
able to the inclusion of error or other distortions as they reconsolidate
after recall (Kensinger & Ford, 2019 ; Scully, Napper, & Hupbach,
2017)— although there remains some disagreement in the literature
regarding the exact mechanism underlying this eﬀect (for a review, see
Lee, Nader, and Schiller (2017).
Just as survey questions might contain memory and inference errors
when indirectly measuring skills, survey questions measuring in-
formation stored within declarative memory are also prone to mea-
surement error because of the very nature of declarative memory. One
example of such a possibility is related to concerns that survey re-
spondents project their own criminal behavior onto their peers when
asked to report their peers' levels of deviant or criminal behavior (for
reviews, see Hoeben, Meldrum, Walker, & Young, 2016; Pratt et al.,
2010). Recently, criminologists examining this projection bias have
relied on the use of structural equation modeling techniques applied to
survey data to observe the presence of this projection bias (see, e.g.,
Rebellon & Modecki, 2014; Young, Rebellon, Barnes, & Weerman,
2014; Young & Weerman, 2014).
Based on the retroﬁt model of social learning, new methods become
available to examine the precise mechanisms involved in projection and
further illuminate this black box in a manner that is internally con-
sistent with the retroﬁt model. For example, research on source mem-
ory— the ability to recall when and where something was learned, from
whom, and through which sensory modality ( Mitchell & Johnson,
2009)— has demonstrated that a combination of carefully designed
probing questions and neuroimaging technology can not only disen-
tangle a memory's source, but also the degree to which the memory
reﬂects a true event or a false memory/memory error (Abe et al., 2008;
Mitchell & Johnson, 2009; Stark, Okado, & Loftus, 2010 ; Volz, Stark,
Vaitl, & Ambach, 2019).
As noted byHoeben et al. (2016), a typical question measuring peer
deviance asks, “Think of your three best friends, in the past three
months how many times have they smoked cigarettes” (109). Should
this question be asked within the context of a study that combines the
use of survey questions with fMRI observations of brain regions, the
fMRI could possibly reveal if parts of the brain associated with the re-
call of episodic, semantic, or autobiographical memories were active
during the answering of the question. If areas associated with episodic
memory are active, then the respondent might be answering the ques-
tion as posed by the survey instrument.

associated with semantic memory, then the respondent might not be
enumerating the deviant behavior of his or her friends but is instead
inferring their behavior based upon the respondent's stereotypes of
them stored in semantic memory. And if the regions of the brain as-
sociated with autobiographical memory are active, then the respondent
is perhaps engaged in the form of projection hypothesized by crimin-
ologists.
Furthermore, this method could reveal the source of the projection.
In cases where regions of the brain associated with autobiographical
episodic memory recall are active, the projections roots might be based
upon the number of times the respondent engaged in the deviant act.
Should regions of the brain associated with autobiographical semantic
memory be active during recall, however, the projection might instead
be rooted in the abstract self-schema the respondent has of being a
smoker. Although speculative, the retroﬁt model of social learning
theory, combined with established protocols in psychology and cogni-
tive neuroscience, enables criminologists to examine these possible
mechanisms in a way that would not be possible using the traditional
social learning theory framework.
Table 1contains a summary of the various forms of nondeclarative
and declarative memories and the research methodologies and tech-
nologies that can be used to investigate their etiological role in criminal
behavior. While the research methodological and technologies listed
are by no means exhaustive, they do provide criminologists with a
starting point as to how components within the retroﬁt model of social
learning theory might be empirically examined.
7. Conclusion
Over the last two decades, renewed criticisms of social learning
theory have focused on the theory's lack of empirical support, failure to
adequately diﬀerentiate between concepts, and inability to explain how
verbal cues operate within its behaviorist paradigm. To address these
issues, a retroﬁt statement of social learning theory was proposed that
updates the theory with contemporary understandings of learning and
memory that have been produced within cognitive psychology and
neuroscience.
The retroﬁt model of social learning theory corrects several pro-
blems inherent to the theory. First, it addresses criticisms that hold little
is actually known about how crime is learned. Unconstrained by the
behaviorist paradigm, the retro ﬁt model speciﬁes various ways in
which skills, conditioned behaviors, episodic memories, semantic
memories, and autobiographical memories all can inﬂuence criminal
behavior and motivation. Second, the retroﬁt model allows for clear
distinctions to be made between di ﬀerent forms of learning and
memory in a way not possible within the previous statement of social
learning theory, which omitted the concept of memory altogether. More
importantly, the forms of memory and learning present within the
retroﬁt model are not merely analytical constructs. Instead, they are
concrete phenomena that can be diﬀerentiated in terms of their neu-
roanatomical and neurophysiological properties — that is, they are
physiologically distinct. Third, the retroﬁt model corrects several errors
present within social learning theory. As a form of learning, operant
conditioning, for example, is only capable of producing motor plans
(i.e., skills), not the forms of symbolic meanings typically attribute to
the theory's concept of deﬁnitions. Likewise, in the retroﬁt model, vi-
carious reinforcement is a special case of operant conditioning, not an
altogether diﬀerent form of learning.
Fourth, an additional consequence of addressing these issues within
social learning theory is that the concept ofdeﬁnitions within it becomes
synonymous with the phenomena of learning and memory. As a result,
the retroﬁt model facilitates new lines of research within the social
learning theory framework. For example, the retroﬁt model introduces
the concept of vicarious classical conditioning into the theory, which
could provide numerous insights into diﬀerent ways through which
criminal motivations might be acquired in regard to emotions.
Additionally, the retroﬁt model's incorporation of semantic memory
allows for numerous insights related to the formation and properties of
schemas to be readily integrated into social learning theory. Lastly, the
presence of autobiographical memory within the retroﬁt model allows
criminologists to begin directly incorporating social psychological
theories of identity and the self with the social learning framework.

Fourth, an additional consequence of addressing these issues within
social learning theory is that the concept ofdeﬁnitions within it becomes
synonymous with the phenomena of learning and memory. As a result,
the retroﬁt model facilitates new lines of research within the social
learning theory framework. For example, the retroﬁt model introduces
the concept of vicarious classical conditioning into the theory, which
could provide numerous insights into diﬀerent ways through which
criminal motivations might be acquired in regard to emotions.
Additionally, the retroﬁt model's incorporation of semantic memory
allows for numerous insights related to the formation and properties of
schemas to be readily integrated into social learning theory. Lastly, the
presence of autobiographical memory within the retroﬁt model allows
criminologists to begin directly incorporating social psychological
theories of identity and the self with the social learning framework.
Finally, the retroﬁt model of social learning theory introduces
criminologists to new research methods and technologies that can be
employed when investigating new lines of research, which potentially
can lead to rapid scientiﬁc discovery in regard to social learning theory.
As noted byCollins (1994), the social sciences have historically lacked
the introduction of new research methodologies and technologies that
allow for the observation of new phenomena or the ability to‘tinker’
with research technologies in ways that allow for new forms of theo-
rizing and empirical observation. Collins notes these‘tinkerable’forms
research methodologies (e.g., combining a telescope with a prism to
allow for the interstellar observation of diﬀerent wavelengths of light)
allow new phenomena to be observed and theorized about, which leads
to scientiﬁc progress. Tinkerable research technologies are diﬀerent
from advances in other forms of research methodologies (e.g., statistical
analysis) that rely on human insights or manipulation of existing data
(e.g., survey data) to generate insights in that they allow for the gen-
uine observation of new phenomena that serve as the objects of scien-
tiﬁc inquiry.
In recent years, criminologists have increasingly argued for the
importation of research methods and technologies from neighboring
scientiﬁc ﬁelds to allow for more rapid scienti ﬁc developments in
criminology (see, e.g., Proctor & Niemeyer, 2019;Wright & Boisvert,
2009; Wright & Cullen, 2012). The research methods and technologies
presented within this paper in regard to the retroﬁt model of social
learning theory take an important step in this regard, as they allow
criminologists to directly observe new phenomena of direct importance
to social learning theory that have traditionally remained outside of the
purview of the theory, as well as triangulate new methodologies with
traditional ones.

Headwaters      A CSB/SJU Faculty Journal 44
PAMELA L. BACON
________________________
Effective Studying is a Science, Not an Art: 
T eaching Students Scientifically-Based 
Study T echniques
Abstract
The typical student never receives formal instruction on scientifically-
based study techniques. Instead, most students utilize ineffective 
methods such as rereading and highlighting. After discussing the 
research on effective and ineffective study techniques, the paper focuses 
on 
my attempts to help students change their study skills by providing 
them with optional reading material, developing an assignment that 
draws on the research, or requiring them to utilize the techniques on 
an exam. Based on my experiences, it appears that requiring students to 
utilize 
the study techniques in order to earn points resulted in greater 
adoption of scientifically-based study techniques than informing the 
students 
about the benefits of t he scienti fically-based techniques. I n  
addition to sharing my strategy to incorporate study skills training into 
an 
upper division course, I also provide a list of studying resources for 
students and faculty.
Keywords
Study strategies, college success, students’ beliefs about learning
Studying for exams was a grueling and frustrating experience for me in 
college. My strategy was to reread every assigned reading, which I had 
diligently highlighted so that nearly every word was pink, yello w, or blue. 
I also would highlight and reread my class notes. Finall y, I would make 
flashcards for every vocabulary word in the textbook, including terms 
that were never mentioned in class. I would skim study guide questions, 
but I was spending so much time rereading and memorizing the book ’s 
bolded terms that I usually did not write out answ ers to the study guide 
questions—after all, if I knew everything in the book, I could answer 
anything on a test!

45                  No. 30 – 2017
 Where had I learned this interesting set of study techniques? 
Learning how to study was not something I was ever taught to do by my 
teachers. Instead, my college studying plan was based on my intuition 
about how to learn, which is how most students develop a studying plan. 
Basing study techniques on intuition results in college students spending 
a substantial portion of their valuable study time rereading the textbook, 
notes, and study guide answers (Karpicke, Butler, & Roediger, 2010). It 
makes sense that if students want to learn something then they should 
keep rereading the information because then it will be stored in their 
memory. Unfortunately, as I will explain later, basing study techniques on 
these intuitive explanations of how learning works results in a reliance on 
ineffective study techniques that actually make it hard to learn. 
 Once students have developed their study strategies, they may use 
their test scores as an indicator of the effectiveness of the technique. Students 
who receive high grades on exams may incorrectly assume that the reason 
for the high grade was the specific way they studied. What students forget 
is that personal experience is a weak form of evidence. When I studied for 
a test using my study method, I was unable to compare my performance 
on that test to my performance had I used different study strategies. Each 
time I received a B+ on an exam, I had no way of knowing that if I had 
simply focused on retrieval practice techniques I might have received an A. 
Instead, I would think that if I had not used my “system,” then I would have 
received a much lower grade. Relying on personal experience also means 
students are unable to rule out alternative explanations for their exam 
scores, such as the exam material focused on material they had previously 
learned, not the study technique used. Relying on personal experience can 
also cause students who receive low exam scores to blame the teacher, exam 
format, or their own lack of ability rather than their poor study techniques. 
Students may even end up deciding they have “test anxiety” or that they 
are “bad at taking tests,” both of which can be terminal self-diagnoses that 
cause students to give up.
 The lack of formal study skills instruction in the K-12 system as 
well as in higher education is surprising because teaching students how 
to learn effectively and efficiently is one of the top priorities of educators.

Headwaters      A CSB/SJU Faculty Journal 46
Usually the teacher’s instructions are simply to “study for the test.” This 
suggestion is often paired with a cautionary tale about what happens to the 
student who only studies for an hour or two for the exam. Thus students 
may get the message that the amount of time is what matters, not the 
study techniques being employed. Additionally, students are often told 
that people have different learning styles, which contributes to students 
and teachers believing that each student needs to figure out how they best 
learn. This also makes it difficult for teachers to make study suggestions, 
as students may dismiss the suggestions because “that may work for some 
students, but I have my own study system that works for me.”
 My experiences as a college student have motivated me to identify 
effective study strategies and to share those techniques with my students 
so that they will have the tools to study more effectively than I did. In the 
next section I will highlight some of the most and least effective study 
techniques, with an annotated list of study skills resources for students and 
for faculty included at the end of the essay. I then will share my attempts to 
teach students how to study and the results of my efforts.
Effective and Ineffective Study T echniques
Contrary to what many people believe, it is possible to identify effective 
and ineffective study techniques by conducting experiments (e.g., Bjork, 
Dunlosky, & Cornell, 2013; Brown, Roediger, & McDaniel, 2014). For 
example, in one experiment students were told they were going to be tested 
on a passage from a textbook (Roediger & Karpicke, 2006a). After all of 
the students read the passage, some of the students were allowed to reread 
the passage until they had read it four times. Others read the passage once 
and then they had to write down everything they could remember about 
the passage (without ever looking at the textbook again). Both groups were 
then asked to predict how much they had learned. The students who were 
allowed to read the article four times thought they had learned more than 
the students who read the article once and then wrote what they could 
remember from the article. One week later they were tested on the passage. 
The results of the test showed that participants who got to reread the article 
actually scored much lower on the test than the participants who only read

47                  No. 30 – 2017
the passage once and then wrote about what they remembered from the 
passage without consulting the passage again. The results of studies such 
as the one by Roediger and Karpicke (2006a) may surprise people whose 
beliefs about learning are based on intuition (including the participants 
in the study, who were unable to predict how well they had learned the 
material). When examining the results of decades of research, there is strong 
empirical evidence that rereading and highlighting are both ineffective 
ways to learn material (e.g., Brown et al., 2014; Callender & McDaniel, 
2009; Dunlosky, Rawson, Marsh, Nathan, & Willingham, 2013). Instead, 
techniques that force the learner to retrieve information from memory, 
such as writing down everything you remember, completing practice tests 
from memory, and using flashcards, are much more effective (Bjork et al., 
2013; Brown et al., 2014; Roediger & Butler, 2011).   
 Passive techniques such as rereading notes may feel useful because 
with the help of the notes the student is able to understand the material 
and it feels familiar (Brown et al., 2014). Rereading helps students develop 
the ability to recognize the material, but does not help them retrieve the 
material from memory (Putnam, Sungkhasettee, & Roediger, 2016). A 
similar process may be at work when students copy their notes by hand 
or type up their notes by copying the material verbatim, making it a 
passive technique that does not require much thought (Bjork et al., 2013). 
Learners often assume that if material feels familiar that it is an indication 
that they have learned the material; however, familiarity is not strongly 
related with actual learning, so students may enter an exam thinking they 
have mastered the material when in fact they are only somewhat familiar 
with the concepts (Brown et al., 2014; Gilovich, 1991).
 The clear message from cognitive research is that learning takes 
effort (e.g., Bjork, 1994). It is the act of remembering material, making 
connections between concepts, putting concepts into our own words, 
creating concrete examples, and asking questions about how and why things 
work that leads to learning (Putnam et al., 2016). Memory is strengthened 
by waiting until one is on the verge of forgetting and then trying to retrieve 
the information, which means that it is more effective to space out one’s 
learning (Carpenter, Cepeda, Rohrer, Kang, & Pashler, 2012). By engaging

Headwaters      A CSB/SJU Faculty Journal 48
in spaced practice, the pathway to the information is strengthened, making 
it easier to recall it in the future (Carpenter et al., 2012). Another effective 
technique is to use elaborative interrogation in which one asks how and why 
things work and then answers those questions from memory (McDaniel 
& Donnelly, 1996). Engaging in elaborative interrogation helps students 
organize new material, making it easier to recall later on and understand 
the concepts more thoroughly (Willoughby and Wood, 1994). 
  Creating from memory a concept map that visually organizes 
the material you are learning and then reviewing what was forgotten or 
incorrect will result in much more learning than looking at a perfectly 
drawn concept map (Schroeder, Nesbit, Anguiano, & Adesope, 2017). 
Retrieval practice is also the best way to know if you have learned the 
material (e.g., Roediger & Karpicke, 2006b). Can you explain the material 
out loud without looking at your class notes? Can you give an example 
of a concept without looking at your flashcard? Can you draw a concept 
map from memory to demonstrate how the material is organized? Can you 
answer the study guide without looking at the answers? Unfortunately, most 
students wait until the exam to learn whether or not they have mastered 
the material.
Exposing Students to the Research on Study 
T echniques and Learning
In every class I teach, I talk to my students about the “science of studying.” 
In addition to spending time talking about scientifically-based studying 
techniques, I also provide students with links to podcasts, videos, magazine 
articles, and blogs that explain the techniques in detail. When I post study 
guides, I remind students of the scientifically-backed study techniques and 
provide them with links to the study skills material. Unfortunately, what 
typically happens was that the students who were already getting A’s might 
glance at some of the resources, whereas the students who could have 
benefitted the most from a change in their study skills would tell me they 
were too busy to do additional reading about study skills or to try a new 
study technique. In fact, it was a great semester when even 2 or 3 students 
looked at the studying resources I had posted!

49                  No. 30 – 2017
 Because of the limited impact of my attempts to provide students 
with optional material on study techniques, I decided to introduce the 
material as a homework assignment so that all students would be required 
to read the material and discuss it. Introductory psychology was the 
perfect class to formally teach students about how to study because the 
material related to topics covered in introductory psychology, students 
tend to struggle on the exams, and many of the students are first years 
and thus may be more open to changing their behavior. In preparation for 
the lab period when we discussed study techniques, students filled out a 
survey describing how they studied and their beliefs about learning. The 
introductory students reported spending an average of 6 hours studying 
for exams. Thus, it is not likely that the poor performance on intro exams 
is due solely to lack of effort. Instead, their specific study techniques 
probably contributed to their difficulties. Students reported that they spent 
about 75% of their study time rereading their notes, rereading their study 
guides (often referred to by students as “going over” their study guide), 
and making vocabulary flashcards. The remaining 25% of their time was 
spent self-testing on material besides vocabulary. Students believed that the 
techniques they used were effective ways to study for an exam. Students 
acknowledged that cramming for an exam was an ineffective strategy, but 
many students reported engaging in this practice because they were so busy. 
Students also acknowledged that there were other retrieval techniques that 
were effective, but few actually used those techniques.
 At the end of the semester, the introductory psychology lab students 
were asked the degree to which they had changed their study techniques 
based upon the scientific research presented in lab regarding effective study 
techniques. About half of the students reported that they had changed 
their techniques, but often times the transformation was rather minor. 
Some students reported that they reduced the amount of time they spent 
rereading their notes, some began using spaced practice, and some reported 
increased self-testing practices. Unfortunately, many students reported no 
change in their studying behavior. Some students explained that they had 
already developed an effective study strategy that worked for them, so they 
had no reason to change. T o be fair, it is likely that some students were using 
effective techniques prior to our intervention. However, it is also the case

Headwaters      A CSB/SJU Faculty Journal 50
that some students were still claiming that rereading their notes and the 
study guide were working well for them. Another large group of students 
acknowledged that they should abandon their ineffective techniques, but 
that it was too difficult to change their habits at this point.
 Having students read and discuss the research on studying did not 
have a dramatic effect on introductory psychology lab students’ behavior. 
Although students modified the amount of time spent rereading, it was still 
the technique they used the most. During lab, some students argued that 
it didn’t matter what the research said, because everyone learns differently. 
They therefore could acknowledge the results of the studies discrediting 
rereading, but maintain the belief that they were the rare exception for 
whom rereading was effective.
Helping Students Developing Their Study Skills
This fall, rather than hoping my junior and senior social psychology students 
would spontaneously change their study skills after reading about the 
techniques, I designed a series of assignments that made using scientifically-
based study techniques part of their homework grade. Creating low-point 
assignments that required students to practice the techniques resulted 
in the most positive changes in studying behavior I have ever observed, 
particularly among students who had less than a 3.0 cumulative GPA. 
 
 I started the studying project by having students complete a freewrite 
at the start of class in which they had to describe how they typically study 
for a psychology exam, focusing on (a) how many hours they tend to spend 
studying, (b) how many days before the exam they start studying (c) what 
they actually do when they “study”, and (d) how effective their techniques 
are. After students turned in their freewrites, I told the students that they 
had a studying assignment for their upcoming exam. Students were told 
that they needed to use retrieval practice, spaced practice, or elaborative 
interrogation techniques to study for the exam (see links in the resources 
section below). Students were told that they needed to try a new technique, 
so if they wrote in their freewrite that they used retrieval practice, then 
I would want them to try spaced practice or elaborative interrogation.

51                  No. 30 – 2017
After class I reviewed their freewrites and identified which techniques they 
should consider, and I commented on any problematic strategies that they 
listed. The results of the freewrites suggested that even juniors and seniors 
relied on rereading their notes and study guides, rereading class material, 
and making vocabulary flashcards that encouraged them to mindlessly 
memorize definitions rather than put the term into their own words. 
Thus, nearly every student had the opportunity to develop more effective 
techniques. 
 Students were assigned to read three blog entries from The Learning 
Scientists about the three techniques and then come to class ready to commit 
to one of the techniques for exam 1. At the start of the next class period, 
I had the students divide up into study groups of 3-4 students with other 
students who were using the same study technique. Students met with 
their groups to talk about how they planned to study for the exam using 
the technique. The groups set up times to meet outside of class to study. 
Later the students turned in individual study plans that required them to 
draw on the material from the blog site and to create a specific plan leading 
up to the exam. Students then provided feedback to the group members 
regarding their plan, which also was graded. Students had to provide me 
with “creative evidence” of their studying, which frequently was a selfie 
of their group studying together, a picture of flashcards asking for real 
world examples of concepts, colorful concept maps, and other fun ideas. 
Finally, after they took the exam they completed a brief survey and wrote a 
reflection on their study techniques. 
 T o further encourage students to try new techniques, I included a 
study guide question that required them to make a large concept map that 
incorporated specific experiments, showed connections between concepts, 
and showed how the concepts differed from each other. It was a challenging 
task for my students. Rather than hoping that the students would spend 
time working on the concept map while they completed their study guides, 
I had students break into their “study groups” and create the concept 
maps on a whiteboard during class. I then went around to each group 
and challenged those who stopped before they had identified all of the 
links and intervened with the groups that had major problems with their 
maps. T o further reinforce the importance of concept maps, I included a

Headwaters      A CSB/SJU Faculty Journal 52
scaled down version of the concept map on the exam, requiring students 
to explain why they had drawn the concept map the way they did. Later 
in the semester, I gave them the outline of a concept map that they could 
use to learn about cognitive dissonance theory for the upcoming exam. 
Students could print off copies of the concept map so that they could 
practice filling it in from memory. Compared to past semesters, this group 
of students did very well on the cognitive dissonance test questions, likely 
due in part to testing themselves with the concept maps. I was surprised 
by how many students told me later that the concept maps were helpful 
to them. For example, one student wrote, “I found that the use of the 
concept map made the information more interrelated or connected. In 
other words, drawing all of the connections between different concepts and 
grouping them into like-minded ideas made retrieving the information a 
lot easier.” In fact, more than one student answered the question on the 
course evaluation about “what aspects of the class contributed most to your 
learning?” by mentioning concept maps.
 I also began providing students with a small number of applied 
questions at the start of class to help them with retrieval practice. I would 
tell them to work in small groups to answer the questions without looking 
at their notes. Sometimes they realized that no one remembered enough 
to answer the question, at which point I would remind them that the fact 
that they could not answer the question indicated they had not yet learned 
the material. These activities are always ungraded, but they did provide 
students with another opportunity to retrieve the information. 
 After the success of the studying project on the first exam, I 
encouraged my students to continue to use the new study techniques, but 
I did not have any homework assignments related to studying for exam 2. 
I noticed that some of the lower performing students in the class showed a 
decrease in their grades from exam 1 to exam 2. In talking to a few students 
it became clear that students had stopped meeting in study groups after 
the first exam. This prompted me to provide students with a small amount 
of extra credit if they could provide me with evidence that they studied 
using one of our techniques for exam 3. This time the evidence was due 
a few days before the exam in order to reduce the amount of cramming 
on the night before the exam. The most common approach was to form

53                  No. 30 – 2017
a study group to quiz each other. Even though students could only earn 
extra credit once, I had multiple students who had worked with two or 
even three different study groups! Although I did not feel that I could give 
additional extra credit related to studying, most of my students continued 
to form study groups before exam 4 and the cumulative final.
Conclusions
Providing students with assignments that force them to develop their 
study skills rather than providing students with the information alone 
led to increased adoption of scientifically-proven study techniques. These 
changes were possible even with students who had spent years utilizing 
other study techniques. On the other hand, it is sobering to think that 
many of my students had completed nearly their entire college careers using 
ineffective study techniques by the time they took social psychology. Based 
on my experience teaching an upper-division content course, I conclude 
that study skills training can be added to a course without detracting from 
the main learning goals of the class. Although I was concerned that my 
social psychology students may object to using class time to talk about 
something other than social psychology, none of the students complained 
that we were spending time talking about cognitive psychology; instead, 
they appreciated how much they had learned about social psychology. 
 Just as we have decided that it’s important for first year students to 
learn the foundational skills needed to be college students, such as how to 
write, read, discuss, and present, perhaps it is time for us to add learning 
how to study to our list. Of course, this is one instance in which First Year 
Seminar or the future version of the course would not be the appropriate 
class to develop study skills. Study skills will be best learned in courses that 
assess learning using in-class exams so that students can develop the skills 
embedded within a course. By helping our students develop their study 
skills, we will be creating an inclusive classroom in which all students have 
the tools needed to learn.

Teaching Students to Study More Effectively: Lessons 
Learned from an Empirical Comparison of a Study Tips 
Presentation and a Review Article
Tara T. Lineweaver
a
, Amanda C. G. Hall
a
, Hanna Throgmorton
a
, 
Sean M. Callahan
b
, and Alexis J. Bell
a
a
Psychology Department, Butler University Indianapolis, Indiana, USA; 
b
Department of Biological 
Sciences, Butler University Indianapolis, Indiana, USA
ABSTRACT
We compared the effectiveness of a “Study Smarter, Not Harder” 
presentation to spending an equivalent amount of time reading 
an article: “Optimizing Learning in College.” One-hundred-sixty 
undergraduate students participated. The presentation and arti -
cle yielded comparable ratings of study tip effectiveness, help -
fulness, and usage. Article readers better discriminated between 
effective versus ineffective and helpful versus unhelpful strate -
gies. Presentation attendees increased their use of all study 
strategies, whereas article readers only increased their use of 
recommended study tips. Results highlight advantages of read -
ing the article over attending this presentation and suggest 
ways to more effectively teach students to study smarter, not 
harder.
KEYWORDS 
Academic success; learning 
sciences; study skills 
instruction; undergraduate 
student learning
The transition from high school to college can be challenging. The increased 
rigors and pacing of the college classroom and the need to learn material more 
independently outside of class place greater demands on students’ ability to 
learn and study effectively (Dresel et al., 2015 ). Unfortunately, in response, 
students often increase the amount of time they spend studying without 
necessarily adapting or improving the specific study approaches they utilize 
(Blasiman et al., 2017 ; Dunlosky et al., 2013 ; Mirghani et al., 2014 ). The 
cognitive psychology literature has clearly established that not all study stra -
tegies are equally effective (Dunlosky et al., 2013 ). Several researchers have 
demonstrated that college students often use techniques that are ill-suited for 
meeting their academic goals (Bartoszewski & Gurung, 2015 ; Gurung, 2005 ; 
Gurung et al., 2010 ; Karpicke et al., 2009 ). Others have shown that students 
may overestimate their learning and its longevity (Bjork et al., 2013 ; Dunlosky 
& Rawson, 2012 ; Garavalia & Gredler, 2002 ; Hacker et al., 2000 ) and that 
students are overly confident in the study approaches they use, even when

those strategies are not likely to be efficacious (Bjork et al., 2013 ). Together, 
these shortcomings in students’ knowledge of study approaches and their 
likelihood of improving performance may undermine students’ academic 
success (Carpenter et al., 2013 ; Dunlosky & Rawson, 2012 ; Hartwig & 
Dunlosky, 2012 ; Lerchenfeldt & Nyland, 2016 ; Liew et al., 2015 ).
These findings have inspired faculty and researchers to recognize the 
importance of teaching college students how to study effectively (Dunlosky 
et al., 2013 ; Marshak, 1984 ; Pressley et al., 1989 ). Nonetheless, very few studies 
have empirically investigated whether explicitly teaching students study tips 
positively affects their study habits. One study demonstrated that simply 
encouraging college students to self-reflect about their study approaches 
improved students’ test scores in an introductory statistics course (Chen 
et al., 2017 ). Francisco et al. ( 1998 ) offered a test-taking skills workshop to 
students enrolled in a general chemistry course and found that students who 
attended the workshop showed a greater improvement in their examination 
performance than students who did not. Two more recent studies introduced 
8- to 12-week study skills workshops and documented significant improve -
ments both in students’ self-reported approaches to studying and in exam 
performance (Mason, 2019 ; Moseki & Schulze, 2010 ). Finally, Biwer et al. 
( 2020 ) compared 21 students who attended three two-hour sessions encoura -
ging awareness, reflection, and practice with study skills to 26 students in 
a wait list control group. The sessions improved students’ metacognitive 
knowledge of study skills, particularly helping them to recognize strategies 
that are not likely to be effective and to instead focus on strategies that lead to 
significant gains in learning.
Not all study skills interventions have been effective, however. For example, 
Jairam ( 2020 ) examined the study techniques utilized by 101 students who had 
taken a first-year seminar focused on study skills. Despite having taken 
a course teaching them how to study, many students (35–51%) reported 
using ineffective techniques (e.g., making lists, highlighting) and very few 
students (4–14%) reported using effective techniques (e.g., creating practice 
questions, relating new ideas to prior knowledge) later in their collegiate 
careers. Similarly, Balsh ( 2001 ) gave students a study tips handout. Although 
they rated the tips as helpful, students reported only utilizing them a moderate 
amount in their everyday studying. Finally, Hedin and Kann ( 2019 ) found that 
students who completed a three-year-long course with frequent modules in 
study skills did not report a significant improvement in their satisfaction with 
their study habits or change their study approaches as a result of the three-year 
investment in teaching them to study more effectively.
Thus, the literature on the efficacy of directly teaching students to study 
more effectively is limited in scope, as well as variable in its methods and 
mixed in its outcomes. One relatively simple approach to teaching students 
to study that has documented some success is a “Study Smarter, Not Harder” 
JOURNAL OF COLLEGE READING AND LEARNING
 171

presentation described by Lineweaver et al. ( 2019 ). This presentation uses 
both evidence from the cognitive psychology literature as well as active 
demonstrations to teach students how to study more effectively and effi -
ciently. The presentation only requires an hour of time and can be imple -
mented in a large group setting, reaching many new college students 
simultaneously. This contrasts with (but can also be offered in combination 
with) the more individualized interventions frequently offered by campus 
learning support centers that generally only target students who are seeking 
academic assistance. In a past study, Lineweaver et al. ( 2019 ) found that 
students who attended the talk perceived the study tips to be more effective 
than alternate study strategies, reported using the study tips more frequently 
in their coursework than a control group of non-attendees, reported using 
the recommended strategies one to three years later, and perceived the 
strategies as having a positive influence on their academic success. Another 
possible approach to teaching students to study more effectively is asking 
them to read information that outlines recommended study tips (e.g., Balsh, 
2001 ). Putnam et al. ( 2016 ) published an article that promotes many of the 
same study tips as the “Study Smarter, Not Harder” presentation and backs 
them with empirical evidence from the cognitive psychology literature. We 
designed the current study to compare the effectiveness of the “Study 
Smarter, Not Harder” presentation (Lineweaver et al., 2019 ) to the effective -
ness of spending an equivalent amount of time reading the “Optimizing 
Learning in College” article (Putnam et al., 2016 ) for teaching students how 
to study more effectively and efficiently.
No studies to date have examined whether Putnam et al.’s ( 2016 ) article is 
effective for helping students improve their studying, and an extensive search 
of the literature did not reveal any past studies comparing the effectiveness of 
a presentation approach to asking students to read an article as a method for 
teaching them better study habits. However, past studies have compared how 
college students learn in more active, hands-on environments versus more 
direct delivery, information-intensive learning situations (e.g., traditional lec -
tures) and have found that active participation in the classroom improves 
learning and increases student performance (e.g., Deslauriers et al., 2019 , 2011 ; 
Deslauriers & Wieman, 2011 ; Freeman et al., 2014 ). Given that the “Study 
Smarter, Not Harder” presentation includes hands-on activities and demon -
strations, we hypothesized that it would be more effective for teaching students 
study tips than the “Optimizing Learning in College” article.
Our first hypothesis was that students attending the presentation would rate 
the tips as more effective and helpful and would report using the tips more 
often in their everyday studying than students reading the article. Our second 
hypothesis was that students attending the presentation would better discri -
minate the effectiveness and helpfulness of the study tips promoted during the 
172
 T. T. LINEWEAVER ET AL.

session from those of alternate study strategies and would report a greater use 
of the promoted study tips relative to alternate strategies than their peers who 
read the article.
Materials and Methods
This study was conducted in two parts, but the data from the two portions of 
the study were combined.
Participants
A total of 160 undergraduate college students at a four-year private 
Midwestern university participated in this study. Although the study was 
open to all students at the university and was advertised widely, many parti -
cipants were enrolled in a psychology course (100- to 300-level), an introduc -
tory general chemistry course, or a course designed for first-year exploratory 
majors due to our direct recruiting of these students. Participants were divided 
into two groups, those who learned the study tips by attending the “Study 
Smarter, Not Harder” presentation (presentation group: n = 91) and those 
who read the “Optimizing Learning in College” article to learn the study tips 
(article group: n = 69). Thirty-eight of these students participated in the 
experimental portion (the first year) of the study and were randomly assigned 
to the presentation ( n = 20) or article ( n = 18) group. The remaining 122 
students were part of the second portion (the second year) of the study and 
participated as a convenience sample of presentation attendees who later 
completed the survey (presentation: n = 71) or a sample who responded to 
recruitment announcements inviting them to learn study tips by reading an 
article and to earn extra credit by participating in the study (article: n = 51).
Table 1 summarizes the demographic characteristics of the participants. 
Both groups consisted largely of first- and second-year students (presentation: 
91.2%; article: 91.3%). The students in the presentation group were statistically 
similar to those in the article group in age ( p = .052) and year in college ( p = 
.061). The two groups did not differ significantly in their gender composition 
( p = .927) or the distributions of their self-reported collegiate GPA ( p = .501).

attending the presentation or by reading the article.

JOURNAL OF COLLEGE READING AND LEARNING
 173

Design
We utilized a 2 × 2 mixed-factorial design. The first factor, session type, was 
implemented between-subjects and indicated whether students learned about 
the study tips through attending the presentation or through reading the 
article. The second factor, type of strategy, was manipulated within-subjects 
and reflected whether the study strategies probed by the Study Approaches 
Questionnaire were endorsed by both the presentation and article (“tips”) or 
were not endorsed by either the presentation or the article (“non-tips”). The 
dependent variables of interest were students’ perceptions of the effectiveness 
and helpfulness of tips versus non-tips, as well as their past versus current use 
of tips versus non-tips.
Our first hypothesis predicted a main effect of session type, with students in 
the presentation group rating tips as more effective, more helpful, and more 
frequently used than the article group. Our second hypothesis predicted an 
interaction between session type and type of strategy, with the presentation 
group showing a bigger difference in their ratings of effectiveness, helpfulness, 
and usage of tips compared to non-tips than the article group.
Materials
Study Smarter, Not Harder Presentation (Lineweaver et al., 2019 )
The “Study Smarter, Not Harder” presentation teaches students eight tips for 
maximizing study time and study effort. The one-hour presentation includes 
empirical evidence in support of most of the tips combined with multiple 
demonstrations designed to illustrate each in a convincing and memorable 
way (Lineweaver et al., 2019 ).
“Optimizing Learning in College: Tips from Cognitive Psychology” Article (Putnam 
et al., 2016 )
“Optimizing Learning in College” is a nine-page article that was published in 
Perspectives on Psychological Science in 2016. It outlines specific suggestions 
from starting the semester to the final exam, as well as offers general study tips 
supported by cognitive psychology research.
Study Approaches Questionnaire
The Study Approaches Questionnaire (see Appendix ) asked students to report 
(1) their perceptions of the effectiveness of 13 different study strategies, (2) 
how often they used each of the strategies prior to attending the presentation 
or reading the article, (3) how often they used each of the strategies after 
attending the presentation or reading the article, and (4) their perceptions of 
how helpful they find each of the strategies on a series of five-point Likert-type 
scales. The 13 study strategies included eight study habits (“tips”) that were 
174
 T. T. LINEWEAVER ET AL.

explicitly mentioned as recommended approaches in both the “Study Smarter, 
Not Harder” presentation and the “Optimizing Learning in College” article. 
The remaining five study strategies (“non-tips”) were not endorsed by either 
the presentation or the article. Any study strategy promoted by the presenta -
tion (but not by the article) or endorsed by the article (but not by the 
presentation) was excluded from the questionnaire. We randomly determined 
the order in which the 13 study strategies appeared on the questionnaire, but 
the order remained consistent across the four groups of questions (effective -
ness, past use, current use, and helpfulness).
To calculate effectiveness, helpfulness, past use, and current use scores, we 
averaged responses across the eight strategies that reflected tips and across the 
five strategies that reflected non-tips for each of the four types of items. Higher 
scores reflected students’ perceptions that the strategies were highly effective and 
very helpful and students’ frequent use of those strategies in the past or currently.
Procedure
This study was approved by Butler University’s Institutional Review Board prior 
to its implementation (approval granted 10/11/17) and was conducted across two 
academic years with different procedures implemented during the two years of 
the study. During the first year, we conducted the study as an experiment. We 
recruited students enrolled in psychology courses and students taking courses 
through the Learning Resource Center (exploratory majors) on campus to attend 
an hour-long session about how to improve their study habits. Sixty-four stu -
dents attended the session. Upon arrival, students were randomly assigned to 
either attend the presentation ( n = 32) or read the article ( n = 32) by drawing 
a piece of paper from a fishbowl. The presentation and article sessions then 
occurred simultaneously in adjacent classrooms. Students in the presentation 
group spent one hour attending the live “Study Smarter, Not Harder” presenta -
tion and participating in the demonstrations associated with it. Students in the 
article group spent one hour reading the “Optimizing Learning in College” article 
and taking notes over it. Students who finished reading the article before the 
full hour elapsed were encouraged to reread the article and to add to their notes 
until the session ended. At the conclusion of the hour, students ate pizza 
provided by the experimenters and received extra credit for attending the session.
During the second year of the study, we presented the “Study Smarter, Not 
Harder” presentation to a group of more than 150 incoming first-year students as 
part of their campus orientation activities. In October, we again offered the 
presentation to a small group of students living in a campus dorm. In total, 169 
students attended one of the two presentations, which were the same as that 
delivered to the students in the experimental study the previous year. To recruit 
a matched article group, we approached students enrolled in introductory 
psychology or chemistry courses or courses offered by the Learning Resource 
JOURNAL OF COLLEGE READING AND LEARNING
 175

Center to attend a session where they could learn study tips by reading the article. 
Eighty-nine students attended an article-reading session conducted using the 
same procedures as during the previous year. These students did not receive 
pizza, but they did earn extra credit for their participation if they were enrolled in 
a class that offered this option.
All students who attended the presentation or read the article received 
an e-mail six weeks later asking them to complete the Study Approaches 
Questionnaire so that we could evaluate students’ perceptions of the study 
tips after they had had a chance to implement them in their courses. The 
Study Approaches Questionnaire was administered online through 
Qualtrics. Students received additional extra credit for completing the 
questionnaire or could instead elect to enter a drawing for one of twenty 
$5 Starbucks gift cards.
Thirty-eight of the 62 students (59%) who attended the experimental ses -
sion during the first year completed the questionnaire. Of the 169 students 
who attended a “Study Smarter, Not Harder” presentation during the second 
year, 71 (42%) completed the online questionnaire. Of the 87 students who 
attended an article reading session during the second year, 51 (59%) com -
pleted the questionnaire.

Figure 1 displays mean perceived effectiveness ratings as a function of session

conducted a 2 (session type) x 2 (type of strategy) mixed factorial analysis of 
variance (ANOVA). The main effect of session type was not significant, F

Frequency of Use of Study Strategies before and after the Experimental Session
Figure 3 shows the mean reported frequency of strategy use pre- and post- 
session as a function of session type and type of strategy. To examine baseline 
versus post-session use of tips versus non-tips following the presentation or 
the article-reading, we conducted a 2 (session type) x 2 (type of strategy) x 2 
(time) three-way mixed factorial ANOVA. A number of main and interaction 
effects reached statistical significance as summarized in Table 2 . For clarity and 
brevity, only significant results will be discussed here, and inferential statistics 
included in the table will not be repeated in the text. First, the ANOVA 
revealed a statistically significant main effect of type of strategy. 
Unexpectedly, across session types and time, participants reported using non- 
tips more frequently than tips. Second, the main effect of time reached 
statistical significance. Regardless of whether they learned the study tips 
through attending a presentation or reading an article, participants reported 
using study strategies (both tips and non-tips) more frequently post-session 
than at baseline. Although these two factors (time and type of strategy) 
interacted significantly, this two-way interaction was further qualified by 
a significant session type x type of strategy x time three-way interaction.

Discussion
The goal of the current study was to compare the effectiveness of attending the 
“Study Smarter, Not Harder” presentation to that of reading the “Optimizing 
Learning in College” article for teaching undergraduate students to study more 
effectively and efficiently. We expected that the hands-on, interactive presen -
tation would outperform the more straightforward information-based 
approach of reading the article as a method for teaching students to recognize 
the effectiveness and helpfulness of recommended study strategies, to increase 
students’ utilization of those recommended strategies in their everyday aca -
demic pursuits, and to help them better discriminate effective from ineffective 
study approaches.
Our results point to both the presentation and the article as good, fast 
approaches for teaching students to study effectively. Although we did not find 
that students who attended the presentation rated the tips as more effective or 
helpful or reported using the tips more frequently than article readers as we 
had hypothesized, both groups recognized the effectiveness and helpfulness of 
the recommended tips over other commonly used study strategies. Even more 
importantly, both groups reported using the recommended study tips more 
often after they learned about them than they had prior to participating in this 
research study. This outcome is particularly positive given that past research 
has, at times, noted a mismatch between students’ perceptions of the help -
fulness of study strategies and their willingness to actually put those same 
strategies to use after study tip instruction (Balsh, 2001 ). Thus, spending 
one hour either attending the presentation or reading the article significantly 
improved students’ self-reported study habits.
JOURNAL OF COLLEGE READING AND LEARNING
 179

At the same time, both groups reported using non-tips more than tips 
overall when averaged across past and current usage ratings, and students 
increased their utilization of both tips and non-tips after the research session. 
Together, these results speak to the popularity of these less effective study 
techniques, particularly among relatively inexperienced (first- and second- 
year) college students (Bartoszewski & Gurung, 2015 ; Carrier, 2003 ; Gurung, 
2005 ; Gurung et al., 2010 ; Karpicke et al., 2009 ), and even after receiving 
training in more effective study techniques (Jairam, 2020 ). They also suggest 
that participants in our study studied “harder” after learning about recom -
mended study strategies than they did before they attended the research 
session. This is not necessarily a negative outcome given that more study 
time may improve learning relative to less study time (e.g., Mazzoni & 
Cornoldi, 1993 ; Nelson & Leonesio, 1988 ; Pelegrina et al., 2000 ). However, 
our goal was to help students study “smarter,” using more effective techniques 
and abandoning less effective techniques to make the time they spend studying 
more efficient.
In this way, contrary to our expectations, the “Optimizing Learning in 
College” article outperformed the “Study Smarter, Not Harder” presentation. 
Students who read the article better discriminated the effectiveness and help -
fulness of recommended study tips over other popular study approaches than 
students who attended the presentation. Article readers also reported 
a significant increase in their usage of recommended study strategies, but 
not their utilization of less effective approaches, unlike presentation attendees 
who increased their use of both tips and non-tips. Thus, article readers showed 
evidence of studying “smarter” after their participation in this study, whereas 
presentation attendees appeared to simply study “harder.” It is likely that both 
groups benefited from these changes to their study habits, but the article 
readers might have benefited more than presentation attendees to the extent 
that using more effective strategies would require less study time to improve 
academic performance.
A number of factors might have contributed to this article outperforming 
this presentation for helping students to differentiate effective from less effec -
tive study approaches. First, the “Optimizing Learning” article was lengthy and 
included more study techniques overall than the presentation. It is possible 
that the students reading the article interpreted the included recommenda -
tions as more comprehensive than students attending the presentation. 
Presentation attendees may have thought that other popular study approaches 
(e.g., highlighting, rereading notes) were not included in the presentation due 
to time constraints rather than because they are not good study techniques.
Second, the article included more explicit statements about what not to do 
while studying, whereas the presentation did less to emphasize the ineffective -
ness of other non-recommended strategies. This omission may have been 
critical given that past research has supported the necessity and helpfulness 
180
 T. T. LINEWEAVER ET AL.

of explicitly including information about ineffective study techniques to 
improve students’ ability to discriminate “good” from “bad” study strategies 
(Biwer et al., 2020 ; Nyland & Sawarynski, 2017 ). We do not believe that the 
more information-focused article approach outperformed the more active 
demonstration-filled presentation approach in our study due to differences 
in how students learn in these two types of environments. Past research has 
clearly documented the superiority of active over passive learning (Deslauriers 
et al., 2019 , 2011 ; Deslauriers & Wieman, 2011 ; Freeman et al., 2014 ). Rather, 
we believe that the article outperformed the presentation because of the 
specific information that was communicated (or not communicated) to stu -
dents by each. Active learning environments should certainly result in greater 
gains in knowledge than more passive ones, but this only holds true if what is 
being taught in that active learning environment is as thorough and compre -
hensive as what is being taught in the more passive learning setting. Thus, the 
results of the current study suggest that the “Study Smarter, Not Harder” 
presentation, as well as other presentations or classes designed to teach 
students effective study skills and habits, should dedicate time and attention 
to teaching students which techniques are not effective in addition to which 
techniques are effective to help them utilize their study time most efficaciously.
Finally, the majority of the presentation attendees learned about the study 
tips before they began their collegiate career (i.e., during their first-year 
orientation or very early in their first semester on campus). In contrast, 
because we recruited many of the article readers later in the academic year, 
the article group had slightly more experience in college classrooms when they 
participated in the study than their presentation-attending peers. Thus, they 
may have had a better sense of what techniques do not work through their past 
attempts to use them without success. This wisdom may have helped them to 
achieve better discrimination between tips and non-tips as a result of their 
participation in this study. Future studies might investigate the best timing for 
teaching students to study effectively. Although we have generally assumed 
that the sooner, the better, students somewhat more advanced in their educa -
tion might be better suited to benefit from study skill instruction due to their 
richer past experiences with what is not effective in college classrooms.
Together, these results suggest that spending an hour reading the 
“Optimizing Learning in College” article improved students’ study habits 
more than attending an hour-long “Study Smarter, Not Harder” presentation 
did. This study only compared one article to one presentation; comparing other 
articles and presentations (or other presenters delivering this presentation) 
might yield different results. Thus, our results might not speak to the type of 
approach to use when teaching study tips as much as it offers suggestions about 
what to include in study tips lessons (which approaches are not effective) and 
when to offer those recommendations to students (after they have had time to 
acclimate to collegiate courses). Additionally, it is important to note that 
JOURNAL OF COLLEGE READING AND LEARNING
 181

students in this study were required to spend one hour reading the article and 
take notes over it in a distraction-free, supervised environment. Simply giving 
students a copy of an article and encouraging them to read it on their own may 
not lead to the significant improvements documented in this research setting. 
Students might not read the article or might not give it the depth and length of 
attention required to improve their understanding of effective and ineffective 
study approaches. If instructors or academic advisors wanted to promote better 
study habits by having their students read an article, they might need to schedule 
class time or outside meeting times during which students complete this task 
and to require students to take notes while reading in a distraction-free envir -
onment, especially since students who may most need the study advice may also 
be least likely to take notes without prompting.
Although the presentation was not as effective as the article at helping 
students recognize which study strategies they should not rely on, it was 
effective at helping students recognize and utilize the study strategies they 
should use. Thus, the presentation did improve students’ study habits. In our 
study, students seemed to prefer the presentation over reading the article. 
Thus, it may be easier to encourage students to attend an interactive presenta -
tion about study skills than to recruit them to come to a scheduled session 
during which they spend an hour reading an article. Adding a few points to the 
presentation to more explicitly point out the ineffectiveness of several com -
monly used approaches might improve the presentation outcomes to make 
them more comparable to those achieved by reading the article, although 
future research would be necessary to empirically investigate this possibility.
Another avenue for future research would be exploring the role of meta -
cognitive ability in the effectiveness of the presentation compared to the 
article. Biwer et al. ( 2020 ) found that students’ metacognitive knowledge of 
effective study approaches increased after their study tips intervention pro -
gram, yet we do not know from our study whether metacognition was influ -
enced by reading the article or attending the presentation. Adding a measure 
of metacognitive ability to a future comparison of a presentation and an article 
would help determine whether certain groups of students respond more 
favorably to one approach than the other.
Although our results indicate that both reading the “Optimizing Learning in 
College” article and attending the “Study Smarter, Not Harder” presentation 
helped students improve their understanding and utilization of effective study 
techniques, our findings are limited by several factors. First, students in our 
study were not given an opportunity to select their own method of learning the 
study tips. Students might show even more improvement if they have the 
option to select their preferred mode of learning the recommended study 
strategies. Second, we did not assess students’ previous experience with 
study skills support services or prior knowledge of effective versus ineffective 
study strategies. Thus, we could not determine whether presentation attendees 
182
 T. T. LINEWEAVER ET AL.

and article readers were equivalent on these factors at baseline or rule them out 
as potential confounding variables in this study. The two groups were very 
similar in their self-reported use of both tips and non-tips before their 
participation in the study, however, suggesting that any differences between 
the groups in their foundational knowledge or past experience with study skills 
training did not translate into substantial gaps between the groups in how they 
approached studying before they heard the presentation or read the article. 
Third, this study was conducted at a small, private Midwestern university over 
a two-year period of time using convenience sampling and evolving recruit -
ment strategies. Our participants were largely female, largely white, and 
exclusively undergraduate students. Research has suggested that teaching 
students to study more effectively can lead to better outcomes when differ -
ences in students’ cultural background, sex, and socioeconomic status are 
taken into account while designing the intervention (Ekuni et al., 2020 ). 
Thus, future studies should compare the effectiveness of a study skills pre -
sentation to that of reading an article in a more diverse student population 
(including adult learners), ideally over a shorter period of time with more 
consistency in procedures across the study. Fourth, participants in the current 
study elected to attend the presentation or read the article, rather than spend 
their time in other ways; they likely represent a highly motivated, self-selected 
group. Future research would be necessary to determine whether the article 
and presentation are both effective with other types of learners, such as 
students who struggle academically or students who lack self-motivation. 
Finally, this study included only indirect outcome measures (students’ percep -
tions of various study strategies and their self-reported use of different study 
techniques). Because past research has shown that study strategy interventions 
can result in better performance on assessments and higher overall course 
grades (Chen et al., 2017 ; Francisco et al., 1998 ; Moseki & Schulze, 2010 ), 
future studies should include objective outcome measures to evaluate the 
overall effectiveness of these two approaches to teaching students to “Study 
Smarter, Not Harder.” Alternately, future research could collect tangible 
evidence of students’ study approaches in the form of their highlighted text -
books, class notes, flash cards, or other study tools to evaluate whether the 
study skills training examined in this or other studies effectively influences 
students’ everyday study habits.
Overall, the current results suggest that spending just one hour either attend -
ing an interactive presentation or reading and taking notes over an empirical 
article can positively influence college students’ self-reported study habits. 
Although reading the “Optimizing Learning in College” article outperformed 
attending the presentation for helping students “Study Smarter, Not Harder,” 
both resulted in improved recognition of study techniques that are effective and 
helpful for maximizing academic performance. Additionally, both reading the 
article and attending the presentation led to more frequent utilization of 
JOURNAL OF COLLEGE READING AND LEARNING
 183

empirically-supported study approaches in students’ academic lives. Together, 
these findings strongly support providing students with a short and simple 
introduction to both effective and ineffective study techniques fairly early in 
their college careers, with an ultimate goal of improving students’ academic 
success as they transition from high school to collegiate educational settings.

Notes on contributors
Tara T. Lineweaver is a Professor of Psychology and the Director of the Neuroscience minor at 
Butler University. A Butler University alumna with Bachelor’s degrees in Arts Administration 
and Psychology, Dr. Lineweaver earned her Master’s Degree in Experimental Psychology from 
the Georgia Institute of Technology. She earned her Ph.D. in Clinical Neuropsychology from 
the San Diego State University/University of California, San Diego joint doctoral program, 
after completing an internship at the University of Chicago Medical Center. Postdoctoral 
training and two years on staff at the Cleveland Clinic preceded her return to Butler in 2003. 
Her expertise includes healthy aging, neurodegenerative disorders, epilepsy, Attention Deficit 
Hyperactivity Disorder, and the scholarship of teaching and learning. A passionate advocate 
for undergraduate research, Dr. Lineweaver invites fifteen or more students to collaborate with 
her on research in her lab each year and also serves as the Editor for the Butler Journal of 
Undergraduate Research. She enjoys teaching Biological Bases of Behavior, Advanced Applied 
Neuroscience and several interdisciplinary co-taught core curriculum courses. She has risen to 
the rank of full professor at Butler, having had the amazing opportunity to focus her career on 
serving the university and the students she loves.
Amanda C. G. Hall is a Professor of Psychology and the Director of Faculty Development at 
Butler University. She earned her B.A. in Psychology from Gettysburg College (Gettysburg, 
PA), her M.A. in Experimental Psychology from Towson University (Towson, MD), and her 
M.A. and Ph.D. in Cognitive Psychology from the University of Virginia (Charlottesville, VA). 
Dr. Hall studies the accuracy of the human memory system and the relationship between 
confidence and accuracy in memory. Her research focuses on what people believe about their 
memories and how those beliefs can be changed so as to be more accurate. One line of her 
research focuses on students and how to maximize their learning in class and outside of class. 
In addition, she is interested in how factors such as mood and emotion can impact our ability 
to monitor the contextual details of our memories. Dr. Hall collaborates with undergraduate 
students in all of her research projects and she enjoys developing new research ideas based on 
the ideas and insights of her students.

Hanna Throgmorton earned her B.A. degree in Psychology with a minor in Neuroscience from 
Butler University in 2018. She was actively involved in two primary research labs during her 
time at Butler, one with Dr. Tara Lineweaver and one with Dr. Ali O’Malley. Ms. Throgmorton 
assisted with numerous research projects, but primarily focused her efforts around student 
study habits and Butler’s Music in Long-Term Care study. She has since transitioned into a role 
focused on identifying optimal career opportunities for individuals and providing training and 
resources to help them grow in desired skill sets, setting them up for success in new career 
paths.
Sean M. Callahan earned Bachelor’s degrees in both Biology and Chemistry from Butler 
University in 2020. During his time at Butler, he was actively involved in Dr. Lineweaver’s 
lab, where he studied the effects of music on sundowning symptoms in patients with 
Alzheimer’s disease. He was also involved in virology research through the Biology depart -
ment. He studied the structure and growth mechanics of mouse hepatitis virus, a noninfectious 
coronavirus, and he coauthored a review paper on the variations in clinical and laboratory 
strains of respiratory syncytial virus. Mr. Callahan is currently working on his osteopathic 
medical degree from the Chicago College of Osteopathic Medicine (CCOM). During his 
first year at CCOM, he was involved in logistics and vaccine administration for the Johnson 
and Johnson vaccine trial at Great Lakes Clinical Trials in Chicago, IL. He currently studies the 
effects of carcinogens and high fat diets on mouse lung tissue and is very interested in the 
medical specialties of Cardiology and Pulmonology.
Alexis J. Bell was an undergraduate student at Butler University from 2018-2020. She was 
a Psychology major and a Neuroscience minor. During her two years at Butler, she was 
a student scientist in Dr. Tara Lineweaver’s lab. She assisted with a number of research studies 
including the Music and Dementia project that involved generating and playing individualized 
music playlists for older adult nursing home residents with dementia. She also served as 
a student co-leader on the current project, which was designed to compare the effectiveness 
of a study tips presentation to that of reading an article explaining the same study tips as ways 
to improve college students’ everyday study habits.

turnaround? Evidence from Ceará state in Brazil
 
Diana Goldemberg
 
 
Priscilla Bacalhau
 
 
Ildo José Lautharte Junior
 
 
June 30, 2020
 
 
Abstract
 
This
note
presents
a
peer-mentoring
program
for
principals
in
Brazil,
​ 
Prêmio
Escola
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Nota
10,
and
discusses
its
impacts
on
second-graders
learning
outcomes.
The
program
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
matches
the
principals
of
schools
with
poor
academic
performance
with
the
principals
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
from
top
performance
schools
and
both
receive
a
small
grant.
As
an
incentive
for
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
active
participation,
a
second
disbursement
of
the
grant
is
provided
to
both
schools,
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
conditional
on
the
subsequent
improvement
of
the
low-performing
school
in
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
standardized
exams.
Exploiting
this
design,
regression
discontinuity
regressions
using
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
school
ranks
indicate
that
low-performing
schools
participating
in
the
program
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
increase
0.18
standard
deviations
the
education
quality
indexes
in
the
following
year.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The
effects
for
low-performing
participants
are
positively
associated
with
school
size
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
and
geographical
proximity
between
paired
schools.
Participation
does
not
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
significantly
impact
top-performing
schools.
These
findings
illustrate
how
school
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
turnaround may be achieved systemically.
